story:
...To Punch a Hole in the Sky

Students For The Exploration And Development Of Space

Students for the Exploration and Development of Space (SEDS), is an international non-profit student organization that was developed to engage the public and spark enthusiasm about Outer Space.

SEDS attempts to accomplish these goals by doing outreach, educating the public about space, launching projects and competitions, and hosting events that introduce people to space. Attempting to show everyone that it is important for us to know about and venture into outer space for the future of humanity.

Metropolitan State University of Denver Chapter of SEDS

Here at MSU Denver, our SEDS chapter is currently competing in the 2015 University Student Rocketry Challenge. This year's challenge is to construct a multi-stage rocket capable of carrying a 1/2lb electronics payload to an altitude of 3000' or greater using less than 640N total impulse. Our team aims to hit at least 5280' carry an additional electronics package with an onboard camera, and include a dual-deploy recovery system. We have our design ready, but now we are in need of enough money to buy the parts to actually build it.

What We Need...

To make this project a reality, we need your help. In order to buy all the parts and supplies for our rocket we need to raise about $1100. This total includes all the materials, electronics, motors, and tools we need to construct our rocket. 

Once we reach this goal, any funds that we continue to raise will be put directly towards NAR membership, and L1 Certification kits for all  team members so that they all may one day hear those magic words that come with certification; "Welcome to high power, now empty your wallet!"  

Please feel free to donate as much or as little as you are able. Our current and/or future spouses will then continue to donate forever after.

The Impact...

The SEDS University Student Rocketry Challenge helps college students supplement their educational experience with cross disciplinary teamwork, project planning, design, engineering, organization, technical writing, photography/videography, and, of course high powered rocketry. We would really like to win this competition and earn a trip to Boston for Space Vision 2015 where the winner will be announced and awarded a $500 cash prize. This award will go back into the SEDS chapter at Metropolitan State University of Denver to help fund current and future projects.

Thank you for helping to make our rocket powered dreams a reality!!

Project Update...

Despite not having reached our Indiegogo fundraising goal, our team was able to pull together enough money to make our high powered rocket a reality. Thanks to our investors, we have our entire rocket built and ready for launch day on July 11th! All that is left to do now is final payload and motor integration. 

A special thanks to Estes Rockets, who donated 7 Pro Series II rocket kits to our team. We've distributed these kits to our team members who have been building them in pursuit of Level 1 NAR Certification. We will be launching many of our team members' L1 rockets in addition to the competition rocket. 

On launch day, one of our members will be filming the launch from the ground while we simultaneously capture drone footage in the air! Soon thereafter, we'll be releasing the footage; however, the launch itself is open to the public and we welcome you all to join us! Please follow this link to the Facebook event for more information.

Thank you all for your support and stay tuned for more updates to come!

story:
The Basics:

Professional licensure in architecture can be a long, laborious, and expensive proposition, which has led to many young professionals delaying theirs goals of licensure, or giving up on them altogether. The PASS aims to highlight recent changes that make the path to licensure simpler, while maintaining the rigor and value of the license, and to encourage young professionals to commit to making a plan and starting early to achieve their goals.

To promote the launch of the PASS Fund, this campaign will run for duration of the AIAS 7-in-7 Campaign, in which the AIAS National President, Charlie Klecha, will prepare for and take all seven ARE Divisions in seven days at the end of May. During the campaign, Charlie will be sharing his experiences getting ready for the exams, and conclude with a reflection on the entire process.

The Full Story:

Professional licensure in architecture entails a combination of Education, Experience, and Examination. In the past, these three components had to be achieved in series, beginning with a professional degree program, followed by internship and other related experience in a professional setting, and concluding with a series of registration exams.

Changes made by the National Council of Architectural Registration Boards, or NCARB, have made it possible in many places to accomplish these three components in a more parallel fashion than was previously possible, allowing for experience to be logged as early as high school graduation, and allowing testing to begin before the experience component is complete.

To date, trends have not indicated that young professionals are capitalizing on this new opportunity to achieve licensure earlier in their careers, and in fact many prolong the process for many years after graduation. The longer the process is delayed, the more difficult it becomes to stick to a rigorous schedule of achieving these benchmarks. Some, in fact, delay the process for so long that they give up on becoming licensed altogether.

The world is in increasing need of licensed architects, particularly with respect to a rapidly urbanizing population, and the myriad new technologies and methods for a more sustainable and responsible built environment. It is the hope that the PASS will serve to help bring ambitious and passionate young leaders into practice.

How We Hope to Help:

There are currently seven divisions of the Architect Registration Exam, each costing $210, which can make it a daunting endeavor for a recent graduate. On top of this, there is a broad, complex, and ever changing wealth of resources and information on the process and how to get through it. 

The PASS is intended to encourage young professionals to make a plan to move toward professional licensure, and begin on that path as soon as possible. The scholarship will be made available to alumni of the AIAS who pass a division of the registration exams within one year of graduating, and will reimburse them for the full cost of that exam. 

To launch the PASS Fund, the AIAS will be producing a weekly series of videos and blogs, called the 7-in-7 Campaign, which concludes with AIAS National President Charlie Klecha sitting for all seven exams in one week. The content produced will help young professionals navigate the vast world of resources and information, and craft a plan that is attainable and ambitious. By setting and achieving these goals, young professionals will no longer see the process of preparing for and taking the ARE as a distant and difficult task, and will be more likely to continue moving toward licensure.

How You Can Help:

By backing the PASS Fund with a donation today, you will be actively contributing not only to the progress and stability of the architectural profession, but also helping young professionals achieve their ambitious goals to help improve their communities and the world through architecture.  

Every donation is essential to the success of this program, and as little as $21 can make a huge difference. Each donation of $210 or more will match you with one or several recipients of the scholarship so that they can personally express the importance of the support you've provided and keep you apprised of the progress they've made.

The AIAS is an independent, nonprofit, 501(c)3, student-run organization dedicated to providing unmatched programs, information, and resources on issues critical to architectural education. Your contribution may be tax deductible to the extent allowed by law. No goods or services are provided in exchange for your generous donation.

Some Questions You Might Have:

Why have you set your target at $50,000?

In order to establish a fund that is substantively self-sustaining, we estimate an initial need for $50,000 to fund the first few years of scholars. Based on the success of our fundraising, and the number of applicants observed in the first year, we plan to adjust our strategy to suit the expressed needs of the program. 

How many scholarships will be awarded?

For the first year, based on the $50,000 target, we plan to limit the scholarship to 100 recipients. We'll continue seeking ongoing support for the fund, and evaluate ways to promote the opportunity to those on the path to licensure. If successful, this program could eventually be extended beyond the AIAS to the entire emerging professional community.

What if a young professional's firm already pays for the exam?

Great question. We put a lot of thought into this one, and decided that it doesn't matter. Existing support does not render one ineligible for the program. Based on what we've seen, only a small handful of recent graduates currently take on an ARE division in the first year. If their employer offers funding, the PASS is a way of even further reducing the financial burden on someone already likely to be coping with a relatively low income. Given the currently perceived income potential in the field of architecture, the prospect of effectively making a profit from moving toward licensure seems to be an apt incentive! Perhaps the additional funding from the PASS will make it possible to schedule the next exam! 

Didn't the ARE used to be offered in only four days? Why is 7-in-7 such a big deal?

Exactly! Many aspiring architects today don't realize that the prospect of taking many exams in a row used to be the only way! While the expressed intention of the 7-in-7 Campaign is not necessarily to encourage others to take on the same approach, it is meant to highlight the fact that much of the content overlaps, and that there is a significant advantage to taking the exams in close succession so that the content is better retained and understood. The ARE should not be about knowing answers, but about understanding principles, and a rapid succession of exams better cements the inter-relatedness of the principles being tested each time.

Other Ways You Can Help

Beyond your financial contributions, we welcome feedback on resources and information that can help young professionals navigate the path to licensure. Every tip and trick may make a world of difference to a young professional, and that content can be featured in the weekly videos and blogs to help them prepare to take the exam!

We can also use all the help we can get in spreading the word! Every share on social media can make a significant difference in the success or failure of this campaign. We hope to reach as many as possible of those with a vested interest in the future of licensed practice!! Share with AIA Components, Firms, individual practitioners, and friends!

Based on the success of our fundraising, and the number of applicants observed in the first year, we plan to adjust our strategy to suit the expressed needs of the program. 
How many scholarships will be awarded?
For the first year, based on the $50,000 target, we plan to limit the scholarship to 100 recipients. We'll continue seeking ongoing support for the fund, and evaluate ways to promote the opportunity to those on the path to licensure. If successful, this program could eventually be extended beyond the AIAS to the entire emerging professional community.
What if a young professional's firm already pays for the exam?
Great question. We put a lot of thought into this one, and decided that it doesn't matter. Existing support does not render one ineligible for the program. Based on what we've seen, only a small handful of recent graduates currently take on an ARE division in the first year. If their employer offers funding, the PASS is a way of even further reducing the financial burden on someone already likely to be coping with a relatively low income. Given the currently perceived income potential in the field of architecture, the prospect of effectively making a profit from moving toward licensure seems to be an apt incentive! Perhaps the additional funding from the PASS will make it possible to schedule the next exam! 
Didn't the ARE used to be offered in only four days? Why is 7-in-7 such a big deal?
Exactly! Many aspiring architects today don't realize that the prospect of taking many exams in a row used to be the only way! While the expressed intention of the 7-in-7 Campaign is not necessarily to encourage others to take on the same approach, it is meant to highlight the fact that much of the content overlaps, and that there is a significant advantage to taking the exams in close succession so that the content is better retained and understood. The ARE should not be about knowing answers, but about understanding principles, and a rapid succession of exams better cements the inter-relatedness of the principles being tested each time.   
Other Ways You Can Help

 Beyond your financial contributions, we welcome feedback on resources and information that can help young professionals navigate the path to licensure. Every tip and trick may make a world of difference to a young professional, and that content can be featured in the weekly videos and blogs to help them prepare to take the exam!
We can also use all the help we can get in spreading the word! Every share on social media can make a significant difference in the success or failure of this campaign. We hope to reach as many as possible of those with a vested interest in the future of licensed practice!! Share with AIA Components, Firms, individual practitioners, and friends!

story:
What is It?

Grace Fed is a better way to study the Bible, taught through short videos and an interactive app.

It's a way to access the riches of the languages it was written in, without spending hours in classes, and memorizing thousands of words.

But, Why?

As good as modern translations of the Bible might be, they simply fall short of conveying the whole meaning of the original languages.

  • English translations struggle to grasp the full meaning of the Hebrew and Greek.
  • Literal translations (exact word for word), are illegible and confusing.
It has been my personal passion to make studying Scripture, in it's original context and language, more accessible. The method I was taught 20 years ago is great, but it can feel intimidating. Grace Fed aims to change that by:
  • Teaching through short, engaging videos similar to Crash Course and Learned Liberty, rather than long lectures; using "micro-learning". learn more (here's the still developing outline)
  • Reenforcing the video lessons with games and guided practice;this is called "distributed-learning", a  proven way to improve student success. learn more
What We Need

We are building a light weight, high quality studio, along with the skills and expertise of collaborators.

  • Here's a link to our shopping list, we want to be totally transparent with you, so it will be kept up-to-date: Wants/Needs
  • We're also want to build a team of volunteer contributors. If you are interested in helping...please let us know.

What if...

...we don't make our goal?
We believe that the skills we're teaching are vital, and we want to make a tool that is of the best quality we can...that's why we need your help. Even if we don't make our full goal, we'll be working hard to still make Grace Fed a reality.
...we exceed our goal?
Everything we raise above and beyond will be rolled into making the quality better, and delivering the program faster.

The Impact

A rich, personal Bible study...

  • Helps you grow closer to God
  • Prepares you to help, counsel, and lead others.
  • Allows good pastors to "go deeper", and not worry about whether or not the congregation "gets it."

Risks & Challenges

We, admittedly have a lofty goal. Our vision is to provide something polished, attractive, and accurate. However, things can get in the way...but we will overcome any hurdles because:

  • We are passionate: everyone from script writer, director, technical advisor, you name it, we want our work to mean something for the gospel and for eternity.
  • We work hard, because we see a desperate need for biblical discernment.

How You Can Help

As with all things, we covet your prayer support. We believe that this project is vital, and we're so grateful for any help we can get. Here's how you can get involved.

  • Pray
  • Send a link to this campaign to everyone you know who might appreciate learning how to study God's Word more closely.
  • If you have any skills in proofreading, editing, animation, music...or any other area that you'd like to donate time, we'd love to speak with you.
Thank you so much.

story:
Who We Are

Bike to Work Spokane is an all-volunteer movement to get people on bikes in Spokane. Each year (this is our 8th), we host free public events the 3rd week of May to get people riding, talking to each other and celebrating our collective awesomeness. 

What We Need

We need money (not much) to host these free community events. This money helps us purchase the things that haven't been donated in-kind by the generous people, businesses and organizations that just give us stuff because they're that cool. City fees, printing, website costs -- that sort of thing. And: We pay our musicians because it's the right thing to do. 

What You Get

This is our official sponsorship benefit list. It's ambitious. If you don't have a couple grand lying around, your support would still mean the world to us. See the bottom of the list for exclusive Indegogo donor benefits. 

Carbon Fiber Frame ($10,000)

Title sponsor (only one available): Attach your company/organization name to the entire set of events and benefit from the maximum exposure possible through all our communication channels.

Gold Wheel ($5,000)

You’ll have maximum exposure through all publicity channels, large logos* on all materials produced and the opportunity for high-visibility participation at all major events.

Silver Spoke ($1,000)

Attach your company’s name to an event not already designated to a sponsor. You’ll have great exposure with medium logos* on materials, the opportunity for high-visibility participation at all major events and inclusion in publicity.

Bronze Gear ($500)

Enjoy exposure with small logos* on materials and inclusion in publicity and booth space at the Annual Pancake Kick-Off Breakfast at Riverfront Park.

Pedal Partners ($250)

Inclusion in our online and print publicity and in news releases and booth space at the Annual Pancake Kick-Off Breakfast at Riverfront Park.

Bike Buddies ($100)

Inclusion in online publicity and booth space at the Annual Pancake Kick-Off Breakfast at Riverfront Park.

Our sponsors benefit from exposure to thousands of Spokane-area residents through:

• Our partners at the county-wide Commute Trip Reduction program disseminate our posters, website and emails to over 45,000 people at 130 workplaces in Spokane County.

• Spokane Public Radio, our media sponsor, promotes Bike to Work Week heavily throughout the month prior to the event. 

• We promote our sponsors directly to our 3,000-strong email database, active social media engagement, print materials and presence at the Spokane Bike Swap and other active lifestyle events.

Indegogo Donor ($20 + BTWW event attendance)

You'll be on our VIP list for Bike to Work Week events: Stop by our Kick-Off Breakfast or Wrap-Up Party to pick up a Bike to Work Week t-shirt and spoke card. (If you can't make it, let us know, and we'll make alternative arrangements to get you your swag.)

The Impact

HUGE. During May 2014, Spokane-area riders logged over 50,000 miles in one week! About 900 riders participated in the 2014 Commute Challenge, and hundreds more participated in the events we hosted throughout the week.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Volunteer! Message us on Facebook or email us at info@spokanebikes.org. 
  • Make an in-kind donation. We'd love any kind of fun swag for prize give-aways. We also have a weird, specific list of needs that we'd be happy to share with you if you give us a holler. 

However you help out, thank you!

story:
Hello! My name is Bianca. I've recently had an awesome, potentially life-changing opportunity presented to me by Omaha Code School - an exclusive, 12-week intensive programming school that only takes a handful of people per session. In 12 weeks, starting at the end of May, I'll be able to program in different languages and create beautiful websites in order to achieve my dream of being a UX Designer. But I need your help to make this a reality!

Omaha Code School is a program that turns novice programmers into hireable web developers in just 12 short, intense weeks. They don't just teach you how to code, though! They help you build a portfolio, resumé and also help you cultivate a network of connections that will help you find a job once you graduate.

I've been a graduate student for 5 years, studying Human Resource Development and Industrial/Organizational Psychology. In the past two years, I started studying creativity and innovation and working in a lab with undergraduate programmers. After studying creativity, I realized that I want to actually be creative! After watching my undergraduate friends create exciting video games and aesthetically-pleasing websites, I realized that I want to take my knowledge of psychology and combine it with programming and web development to be a UX Designer. 

So why do I want to attend Omaha Code School? Because they'll teach me everything I would learn in those classes, maybe even more, for a fraction of the price and time! I'm confident that I'll be able to find a job by the end of the year. I'll be able to learn so many tech-relevant skills that will broaden my knowledge and experience.

Here's where your help comes in! Omaha Code School's tuition is $7500. It's super reasonable compared to other code schools across the country. Unfortunately, I've been living on a graduate student salary for the last 5 years. 

In addition, the program is so intense that you can't work while you attend. That's great for focusing, but not so great for paying bills. This being the case, I will not be able to work a full job to pay my rent and other expenses. What little savings I do have are earmarked for taking care of my fantastic dog, Penny. I have some money saved up, but this is where I need your help.

I will be putting all $5,000 raised here towards the $7,500 cost of tuition, so rest assured your money will be put to good use.

story:
Help me get a Masters Degree in the UK

My name is Amadu Sandy and I am a journalist. I work for BBC Media Action in Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone and a city at the centre of the Ebola crisis. We’ve been working hard during this difficult period to bring meaningful information to our audiences about the disease. This crisis has underlined for me the importance of a sturdy, effective and ethical media.

The media is another sector in Sierra Leone in great need of development. If you are generous enough to support my further education, I promise that you will also be supporting the development of a free and open media in the longer term.

Sierra Leone is one of the poorest countries in Africa. More than half the adults here can’t read or write; most of the country has no access to fresh, piped water or electricity; there are very few doctors – even before the Ebola outbreak the healthcare system was at breaking point.

But I love this country, I love Mama Salone (the name used by the citizens of Sierra Leone, to show their love for their country).
I was born here 26 years ago, I went to school here, I studied here and I got my university degree here. My family lives here. And I want to help the people of Sierra Leone improve their lives. Currently I am responsible for providing financial support for 15 members of my family. But the cost of a year in the UK is not something I can cover from my own resources

In order to help improve more lives, I need to study further. I have been accepted by several universities in the UK to join their Masters programme. 

 But if I can’t raise £15,000 I won’t be able to go.

So can you help?

Thank you.

“Amadu is a man with a large appetite to learn, a man with ambition, and a man who I believe would benefit enormously from overseas experience. I believe him to be someone who cares deeply about the difficulties his country faces and who wants to help his country overcome them.”

Tim Mansel, International Freelance Journalist.

story:
Loving, Professional Theatre Training Since 1997

The Columbia Gorge School of Theatre is very excited to embark on its 19th summer providing professional theatre education for youth of all ages! 

CGST is a performing arts-focused 501(c)3 nonprofit sleep-away and day camp founded in 1997 that offers rigorous actor training programs for youth of all ages from around the world. During camp, students have the opportunity to take Voice, Dance, Meisner Acting, Improvisation, Stage Combat, Theatrical Design and other diverse classes while working towards producing and performing culminating plays and musicals. As teachers, counselors and directors, we pride ourselves in creating an emotionally and physically safe environment, free of negative criticism and full of fun, where students can flourish both personally and professionally.

Summer camp can be a life changing experience for many kids. At CGST we believe very strongly in the impact our emotionally safe environment can have on our students. Every year, we are amazed by the power of young people to love and be loved without judgment when they are supported by a community of Peace & Love. While professional acting training is at our core, it is the CGST experience of community and family that sets us apart.

After 18 years, we are proud to have reached over 2,000 young people from all over of the world, now joined together in a community of Peace & Love, and an appreciation of the performing arts. We hope to reach even more young people in 2015! But we still need YOUR help!

We believe no child should have to miss out on this amazing opportunity due to financial restraints. Summers at CGST range from 1-5 week long sessions, including 2 day camp options for students aged 8-11. CGST tuition can cost families between $939 and $3999 for overnight sessions, and $379 for day camps. Tuition costs cover: 

  • 45 hours a week of class instruction and rehearsals
  • 3 meals a day, plus evening snacks
  • Housing in the Lewis and Clark College dormitories
  • Production of a play, musical or film
  • 2014 CGST Camp t-shirt

Our Scholarship Fund goal of $15,000 has the potential to help many of our new and returning students enjoy a summer at CGST though both partial and full tuition scholarship opportunities.

Every Dollar Counts!

Even if you can only spare a dollar, your sponsorship will be going towards making our CGST dreams a reality! By donating to our campaign you are not only helping our students, but also earning some pretty cool gifts for yourselves! Sponsors will be receiving awesome SWAG from us including:

  • Personalized thank you notes from the 2015 CGST family!
  • Group photos of the 2015 CGST campers, perfect for spicing up any living room wall!
  • A 2015 CGST camp T-shirt, so you can match our awesome and oh-so-fashionable campers and staff!
  • Free admission for two to our end of the summer productions (A full production play, musical and original film)
  • Free advertising for your business in our weekly production programs
  • Recognition as a Bronze, Silver or Gold Sponsor on our website and in our weekly production programs
  • Exclusive invitations to CGST special events throughout the summer and the year!

By making a donation to our Scholarship Fund, you will be doing more than providing an enrollment opportunity – you will be giving that student a chance to thrive in their element, grow as an artist, and gain life-changing confidence, as well as life-long friendships. Your sponsorship would be a great help as we aim to encourage, empower and support our students’ growth as young artists. 

Beyond the $$$

Even if you are unable to support our campaign financially you can also become a sponsor by SPREADING THE WORD. Your support, love and encouragement are some of the greatest gifts we can ask for! 

Thank you again for your support of the students at the Columbia Gorge School of Theatre!

Peace & Love,

The CGST Family

story:
What this is.

My name is Hayden Townsend and I am an avid outdoorsman.

I came across this issue and others nationwide and want to help educate the public and change minds and save a national treasure.

If something is not done to stop the commercial catch of trophy IE brood stock catfish from public waterways we will lose generations of a prized sportfish.

These large catfish are the best defense against invasive species.

They have a voracious appetite for Zebra and Quagga muscles Silver and bighead carp and others. They are the true measure of the health of our waterways.



We need funding for software, webhosting, and equipment to create and run the site
The software license is expensive over 900 dollars of the total will go to that.
The webhosting and advertising are the other big expense we are looking at over 1500 dollars.
The equipment is expensive as well. We are looking at approximately 1100 dollars for that.

When the site is up for top tier donors we are giving away email addresses with the groups name on it as a perk and premium membership. Premium memberships when the site is open will be 25 dollars a year.

If we do not reach the goal we will use the funds to the best of our abilities to get the site started

 

 

This project could impact how a major sportfish is viewed nationwide.

 
 


 
 

If you cannot donate please share and spread the word.

I came across this issue and others nationwide and want to help educate the public and change minds and save a national treasure.If something is not done to stop the commercial catch of trophy IE brood stock catfish from public waterways we will lose generations of a prized sportfish.These large catfish are the best defense against invasive species.They have a voracious appetite for Zebra and Quagga muscles Silver and bighead carp and others. They are the true measure of the health of our waterways.We need funding for software, webhosting, and equipment to create and run the siteThe software license is expensive over 900 dollars of the total will go to that.The webhosting and advertising are the other big expense we are looking at over 1500 dollars.The equipment is expensive as well. We are looking at approximately 1100 dollars for that. When the site is up for top tier donors we are giving away email addresses with the groups name on it as a perk and premium membership. Premium memberships when the site is open will be 25 dollars a year.If we do not reach the goal we will use the funds to the best of our abilities to get the site started    This project could impact how a major sportfish is viewed nationwide.        If you cannot donate please share and spread the word.

story:
DECA prepares emerging leaders and entrepreneurs for careers in marketing, finance, hospitality and management in high schools and colleges around the globe

Greetings from the Mound Westonka DECA Club!

As member of the DECA Organization at Mound Westonka High School, we have earned an opportunity to attend the International DECA Conference in Orlando, Florida by successfully earning one of the TOP THREE places in each of our competitive events at the Minnesota State DECA conference held March 8-10 in Minneapolis.
Our Westonka DECA Team will be sending 32 members to compete at the International level, needless to say an accomplishment we are extremely proud of. Each member of the team put a great deal of energy and hard work into their competitive events and we are thrilled to have an opportunity to attend this important event.  
In order to represent the community at the International conference, we must raise $38,000 to fund the trip.  The money is necessary to cover transportation, accommodations, and admission to the competition.  
We would greatly appreciate any and all financial assistance you would be willing to provide.

All donations will go directly toward the funding of this important educational experience.

For more Information about DECA check out
 http://www.deca.org/high-school-programs/high-school-educational-conferences/international-career-development-conference-hs/

story:
From Garrison to Garden

We wish to thank all supported this campaign through donations, spreading the word and praying with and for us.  Whilst we may not have made all our goal we will be able to fully kit out the boys bathroom and install new toilets in the other 3 bathrooms, we have been donated the fencing, we still have other equipment and fittings to purchase.  But thanks to you all, we are making a good start.  We will continue our ongoing fundraising and progress news on our  https://www.betterplace.org/en/projects/6480-th...   please join us there.


It has come to our notice that there are some (particularly from the USA), who think because this is coming from Jamaica, that this appeal is a scam.  Not so at all, anyone looking for confirmation of our existence and work need only Google "Grffin Trust Jamaica" or "Moira Morgan Jamaica", our history is there for all to confirm.  Please check us out and help us if you can.......

Thanks to cash raised to date and gifts in kind donated by local suppliers

 (**3 smoke alarms, 1 bathroom set and 500ft x 6ft chainlink fence  [we still need to buy posts and cement]) 

as at 01/5/2015 we only require  £3,175 **   

only 10days left to go, you can help us make it.....   


My name is Moira Morgan, born in Dublin to a long line of social activists and, as my father would say 'penniless philanthropists'.   From tweens to date volunteering, campaigning, lobbying, and working with and on behalf of children and youth has been my passion and is second nature to me.  

I first came to Jamaica in 1977, spending a couple of months in the then, up and coming working class, residential area of Tower Hill, Kingston 11.  This was just before the political 'war' that preceded the 1980 election.  On my return to Tower Hill eighteen years later, I found, a zinc fenced, poverty stricken, socially disenfranchised, politically tribal, inner city garrison community with a different gang and 'don' on every corner.  What haunted me most was the sound of children crying. Their heart wrenching cries constantly being heard above the sounds of gospel singing churches, raucous dance hall djs and the nightly barrage of gunshot.

With the help of family and friends The Griffin Charitable Trust was established to support the work which I had already begun and it became a charity in its own right in Jamaica in 2005.

Through the Griffin Charitable Trust education and literacy programmes have been established.  Refuge and safe havens have been provided for young children, girls fleeing sexual predation and for women fleeing domestic violence.  Other projects undertaken have included gang mediation programmes and care for the elderly.

In November 2007, the horrific living conditions of two local elderly men in need of life end care, prompted me to beg some furniture from the local Hilton Hotel to furnish the unused second bedroom in my rented house.  The two gentlemen were moved in and cared for throughout their last days, by myself and two local volunteers.  The Sanctuary was born.  Shortly after this, a sibling group of three children (18mths, 3yrs and 5yrs of age) took up residence.  A few months later another sibling group of three children arrived (6, 8 and 12yrs of age) which necessitated more begged furniture.  The Sanctuary has been the only place that our sibling groups can remain together as a family, nurturing growth and providing an environment that facilitates healing from their shared past of abuse, neglect and violence.

  

                    2007                                                                      2012

Thanks to Digicel Foundation Jamaica, we have been able to buy our own property in Yallahs, St Thomas 

                                                2015                                                                2015

Thanks to a grant from Digicel Foundation Jamaica and the gifts collected through our previous campaign and website, we were able to purchase, this beautiful property on 1/2 acre by the sea.  The main house is 4 bedrooms 4 bathrooms, plus there is a 2 bedroom cottage attached in which the elderly vendor has been granted occupancy for life, this enabled us to buy within budget.  The children are all settled happily into their new home and school environment (with a special needs unit for our girl with learning disabilities),  close to all amenities, able to participate in extra curricula activities at school and in the community, for the first time.......   
We call our new home, The Children's Oasis, a permanent place, providing a temporary space for refreshing, renewing and nurturing children and their families as they heal from the traumas of their separation and it's causes.
In addition to providing a home for up to 12 children, The Children's Oasis will facilitate therapeutic family interventions and a contact centre for children in care and those from separated families, in a neutral, child centred space.

First of it's kind in Jamaica

For  children in care, particularly foster care, there is no neutral place for them to have face to face family contact.  In Jamaica, when it happens, if it happens, it does so over the desk of a social worker, not at all conducive to real interaction between child and family and one of the major reasons why  so many family reunification's fail and too many children leave the care system at 18, unattached to either state or family, making them more vulnerable.  

At The Children's Oasis, family contact can be maintained on neutral ground, with services to enable and encourage family reunification, in a safe, monitored space that is family friendly and child centred, with the well being and safety of the children, our first priority.  

This will be the first such centre in Jamaica, providing supported, monitored or supervised child contact and a wrap around healing process for children in need and their families.

Before we can do anything else, we have to do some refurbishing to bring the house up to scratch in order to meet the health and safety standards for residential care.  The house is 40+ years old, as are the plumbing and bathroom and kitchen fittings, and we need to install smoke alarms, fire extinguishers.  Without meeting the required standards, we will not be able to continue to care for the children or expand our services.   

We have professional tradesmen and labour on hand to do the work free of cost, we just need to buy the materials !!!!!

What We Need 

  • 4 eco-flush toilet pan and cisterns @  £95                    =              £380. £0.

  • 4 wash-hand basins with vanity      @ £143                     =              £572  £414

  • 4 sets shower fittings                         @ £190                      =            £760  £570

  • 1 Double Kitchen Sink/Drainer        @ £200                     =            £200

  • 10 smoke alarms                                   @ £48                       =            £480 £336

  • 3 Fire blankets                                       @  £95                     =              £285

  • 3 Fire Extinguishers                              @£190                    =              £570

  • Perimeter fencing (500ft run                                                                                                   6ft chain link and posts)                       @ £4per ft run      =          £2,000 £800

  •                                      Total Required   £5,247 **

    **3 smoke alarms, 1 bathroom set and 500ft x 6ft chainlink fence  donated by local suppliers (we still need to buy posts and cement),  

  • as at 01/5/2015 we only require    

     £3,175 **              

  • This will enable us to keep our children together, it will pave the way for regular monthly family contact for them and up to 500 other children per year who are separated from their families, with specialised therapeutic interventions for 140+ children and their families, working towards safe, sustainable family reunification.

Whether or not you can donate, please spread the word...... Use the sharing tools provided here.....

story:
CommonTruce Community: Professional Dress Workshop encourages the transition of young boys to young men. This program hones on the importance of appearance by providing our youth with the necessary tools and resources to be successful in today's society. CommonTruce Community will directly address young men and provide education on grooming, hygiene, and presentation.  In addition, young men will learn how to properly tie a tie using the four hand knot method.

With your support, CommonTruce Sock + Tie Drive will provide each participant with a pair of socks along with his own tie. Together, we can impact these young men through positive mentorship, increase self confidence, and aid in the success of future generations.

Thanks in advance!

story:
Carlos wakes up at dawn, or even a few minutes earlier, and with the empty belly he goes to the landfill of his town in Nicaragua: the chureca, the basurero!
The day starts with a "hook" in hand...his best mate: a stick with three tied harpoons at the bottom, which allows him to hook the "worth" waste before others (plastic and aluminum can be sold for a few pesos)!

The chureca gets soon crowded with children, the truckloads of waste arriving continually and raising a big fuss, feeding the enthusiasm of the "researchers" who often jump on them while still driving; hearths multiply during the day, the air becomes black with toxic smoke, and with watery eyes Carlos’ hands dig incessantly.
Carlos eats what he finds in the trash; his brother, who has a noticeable mental delay (it was indeed caused by some toxic product he ate during childhood) and his mother joins him in the evening holding his sister in her arms, born just a few months ago. She bends over the mountains of garbage and collects a can, the baby bursts out crying. She coughs and calls Carlos, it's time to go home.

Carlos lives in a metal sheet shack, without floor. He has never gone to school, he has never had a toy or never held a pencil; he spends his days in this terrible way, and so many others like him, going from an early childhood right to adolescence, taking then the wrong way and losing track.

Carlos does not look up when he is called, he does not have time to waste on small talk with strangers, he has to work, earn some money for his mother, his sister and his brother...like so many others, Carlos might become ill and die too soon, with his hook leaning against his grave.
It is said that children of the landfill "Buscan la vida"... However, we can save them!

The feet of the chureca children cannot be described, hands rummage in the garbage, and the true color of their skin can only be imagined.
Carlos, Loupe, Bryan, Francis, Pedro...They are our aim, the purpose of our efforts. Our raising is for the children who work in the landfill of Chinandega and who do not have the opportunity to go to school, a school that actually lays 500 m away but is unable to hold expenses for all these unfortunate children.

Time4Life International Foundation has been working on in this reality in Nicaragua for two years now and 150 children have been saved, but there are still too many left to be helped!

Our project, in collaboration with El Arbor Foundation http://www.elarbol.nl/?lang=en has as goal a life and a future for the children of the Chureca: they are taken out of the landfill context and its terrible work, and taken to school where they receive food and educational, health and recreational assistance.

With the sought funds the Foundation will take care of these children for a whole year, improving the school and services conditions, and providing as well economical assistance to families that need support and that show willingness to work together to create a new future for their children.
The motto adopted by Time4Life is "Whoever saves one life, saves the whole world" and we can do that!

How to contribute:

1. Contribute with a donation to the project through indiegogo for the year 2016

2. Follow Time4Life International Foundation on facebook
follow Time4Life International Foundation on facebook https://www.facebook.com/groups/196246990550253...
and find out all projects in Nicaragua and other countries

3. SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN ON FACEBOOK

4. - Care of the project "distance support"
- Care of the project "distance support", which is active in Nicaragua and in the rest of countries where the Time4Life International Foundation http://www.time4life.it/
operates

story:
Our vision: Improve education conditions

It is estimated that  4 out of every 10 inhabitants of El Salvador live in poverty. El Salvador has one of the highest rates of criminal activity in the world. The country is known as the most violent in Latin America. The public education in the country is deficient. 

The goverment of El Salvador is currently implementing a program to provide computers to public schools throughout the country. With them, schools will be able to teach their students a variety of computational skills that are highly valued in today's labor market, giving them a chance to gain access to better jobs in the future. However, many schools in the least privileged zones of the country cannot benefit from the computers provided since they don't have an adequate infrastructure to use as a computer classroom.


We are a group of passionate students who want to make a change in education in Cantón Las Granadillas, a small community in Santa Tecla, El Salvador, whose inhabitants live in poverty. We work to give to the children in this community the oportunity of a better education, and help them develop valuable skills. 
The school in Cantón Las Granadillas has a room with the purpose of serving as a computer classroom. However, it is in very bad conditions. It has a leaky roof, it isn't secure enough to store the computers and it has no useful furniture. In order to be able to give the children a proper education, the classroom has to be restored so it can be useful again. The main challenge is the roof, since it will have to be changed completely.


What we need:

The design of the proyect has already been made free of charge by a professional  arquitect. According to her estimations, the funds needed to complete the project rise to $3,800. Of that, $2,500 will be used to pay for the materials needed. The labor costs are $1,100. The rest will be used for the transportation of the materials. These include:

angles

building sheets  

corrugated iron

squared tubes

boxes electrodes

metal cutting discs

anticorrosive paint

thinner

plywood plies

bizarros

chapas

sikaflex sausages 

tramos


With your help, we will be able to repair the leaky roof and reinforce the security in the windows, roof and doors, which is very important since the school is located in a very insecure area, and we need to make sure the computers don't get stolen. Also, we will make the furniture suitable for the use of the computers and paint the classroom. With that restoration, the room will be in conditions to be used as a computer classroom, and the 300 children currently studying in the school in Cantón Las Granadillas will have a proper education in computer skills.

The school in Cantón Las Granadillas has a room with the purpose of serving as a computer classroom. However, it is in very bad conditions. It has a leaky roof, it isn't secure enough to store the computers and it has no useful furniture. In order to be able to give the children a proper education, the classroom has to be restored so it can be useful again. The main challenge is the roof, since it will have to be changed completely.


   What we need: The design of the proyect has already been made free of charge by a professional  arquitect. According to her estimations, the funds needed to complete the project rise to $3,800. Of that, $2,500 will be used to pay for the materials needed. The labor costs are $1,100. The rest will be used for the transportation of the materials. These include:

angles
building sheets  
corrugated iron
squared tubes


boxes electrodes
metal cutting discs
anticorrosive paint
thinner
plywood plies
bizarros
chapas
sikaflex sausages 
tramos



With your help, we will be able to repair the leaky roof and reinforce the security in the windows, roof and doors, which is very important since the school is located in a very insecure area, and we need to make sure the computers don't get stolen. Also, we will make the furniture suitable for the use of the computers and paint the classroom. With that restoration, the room will be in conditions to be used as a computer classroom, and the 300 children currently studying in the school in Cantón Las Granadillas will have a proper education in computer skills.

story:
Short Summary 

 

A building of the Monastery was returned devastated in the possession of Benediktine nuns in the year 2012 after nationalisation. Benediktine have decided to use that building as an additional integration point with public and local community as well as source of financial income for the Monastery which should ensure its sustainability. Unfortunately, the building was devastated and it required complete rehabilitation.

As the building has large space, two floors and ground floor, Benediktine have decided to establish museum at second floor and bakery and souvenir shop at ground floor and first floor. The rehabilitation of the building have started, but unfortunately it was stopped due to the lack of funds for the completion of the remaining works and purchase of the furniture and equipment. Therefore, we have decided to launch this campaign.

Multiple and continuous interaction between residents of Pag and their nuns took place through education. In fact, the first written information about organized teaching girls and women at St. Margaret Convent dates back to 1579th stating that the nuns taught girls from the island in reading, writing and embroidery. Pag lace, inscribed on the protected UNESCO's list of world intangible heritage, from the peace and quiet of the monastery is committed, through organized teaching, to women of the island, and they have continued this work by applying it as a decoration in dress and as a separate item.

 Pag lace, from the Monastery's collection
In addition, local people and their guests enjoy the fresh sweet biscuit baskotin that Pag’s nuns baked by medieval recipes. Today, it is still alive the custom of giving in marriage a cake shaped like a heart that is called strika and a sweet round called kolacic. In addition to preparing pastry, sisters produce a variety of liquors and medicinal creams.
Monastery's products: Barrel Aged Port, Herb Brandy, Altar Wine, Limoncello Liquer
We would like to mention that  seven hundred years of continued existence of the Monestry of St. Margarita in Pag, Croatia, will be celebrated in the year of Our Lord 2018.

As a part of the five-year preparation for the celebration of this anniversary, the exhibition Seven century of the Benedictine in Pag, through stories, articles and photographs, is intended to offer an overview of life and work of nuns of the island Pag in the Republic of Croatia. In the life of the monastery is reflected the history of the island of Pag told in the quiet atmosphere of prayer that devise work through sewing lace, making biscuit baskotin, a variety of pastries and other items, which are threads that weave a connection between the inhabitants of Pag and their nuns. In the space where faith gives meaning to life the fruit is creation and preservation of works of art.

Main altar of the monastery's church
The museum exhibition will show a little of everything, it will explain spiritual binder between women who pray and objects that testify to the faith expressed in action guided by the motto ora et labora (pray and work).

Sister Rozaria sewing Pag lace

  Reliquary of the Holy Thorn

The trial of Jesus

 Statue of the Virgin and Child with Angels

What We Need & What You Get

Rough construction works on the renovation of the museum and souvenir shop have been completed. Now, we need to complete the fine construction and installation work, as well as to equip both areas in order to establish  functionality of the museum and souvenir shop.

In the museum we intend to install ethnological room, showcases with exponents, lighting, multimedia and electronic equipment for the presentation of the museum settings in several languages, as well as equipment for video surveillance and security.
In the souvenir shop we intend to purchase counter to the seller, showcases for souvenirs, and IT / electronics equipment needed for the sale of souvenirs and tickets for the museum.

We also intend  to install an elevator in order to enable access for the disabled persons to the museum, as well as access for all other visitors.

For the reconstruction of the garden required are preparatory works, take a barren land, lead and arrange fertile soil, plant Mediterranean herbs, perform the waterproofing and construction work on the patio, and to install adequate outdoor lighting and hydrant installation. As part of the garden 25 m2 of solar panels should be installed with accessories.
Herbs from the garden will be used for making drinks and other products of medicinal plants. These products will be offered in the gift shop.
Moreover, we need to equip the bakery and to purchase 200 boxes for packaging products in order to start selling Baškotini and cakes.
After completion of construction works at the museum, gift shop and garden, Benediktine intend to employ four people. Two employees would be employed for the production and sale of Baškotini and cakes, and two for work in the gift shop and museum.
Benediktine intend to organize workshops for making of the Pag lace within the museum in the autumn and winter, and in the spring and summer such workshops in the garden.

The Impact

The first aim of the project is to present cultural and spiritual heritage of
the St. Margarita Monastery to world, to you.

The second aim is to improve production of bakery products and you will have possibility to taste them.

We intend to commence work of the bakery, museum and souvenir shop based on
the social entrepreneurship as soon as possible. Our intention is to create at least four working places after completion of this project.

We expect that these activities will ensure financial sustainability for
the spiritual work of the Benedictine nuns.

 

Risks & Challenges

 We intend to collect total amount with this campagna in order to be able
to complete project; however there is no sufficient guarantee for that. If we
do not collect sufficient funds, we will implement project step by step. Firstly,
we intend to complete bakery and souvenir shop. As a second step, we intend to
complete museum and to install elevator. As a final step, we intend to complete
works in the garden and to install solar panels. If required, we will launch additional
campaigns for second and final step or prolong this one.

  

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone can give monetarily as much as they would like, but you can still contribute. Please help us support this project by spreading the word about this campaign, sharing it using the Indiegogo sharing tools, and telling others stories about Benedictine and Monastery of St. Margarita.

 

 

Our Core Team

There've been so many people involved in the work of the Monastery and this is our core team for this campaign:

Benediktine Sister Ann Halilović, Director

Marina Kostić, IT Support

Zoran Kostić, Senior Project Manager

story:
HELLO!

I’m Amelia McGee—mother, parent educator, master of public health, and Seattle resident. I am asking you to donate to my campaign to start an educational program for new parents in the Seattle area. It’s called Happy Babies Parent Education. It will support new parents in their journey, connecting parenting peers to each other and to a trusted educational resource.

WHY YOU SHOULD DONATE TO HAPPY BABIES

In modern parenting, so many of us live far away from our families. We lack our proverbial village for childrearing. We don’t know where our mentors are. We are seeking our people. Parenting is THE HARDEST thing we will ever do and we need to be supported!

I am asking you to donate to Happy Babies Parent Education because you know the value of having:

  • Someone who can answer ALL. THE. QUESTIONS. and help you find your way as you care for your baby and grow yourself as a parent.
  • Somewhere for you and your baby to get out of the house on a regular basis.
  • “Peer-ents”! You are in the 3-am-up-to-your-eyeballs-in-poo-and-tears trenches together and their questions are your questions.

Maybe you had these pillars of support or maybe you longed for them. Either way, you know how critically important they are. I know because I had them—and I am invested* in bringing them to other parents.

*While I personally believe that parenting support is priceless, I have also literally invested over $700 of my own money in creating this program.

WHAT YOU ARE SUPPORTING

Your donation towards our goal of $5,000 will pay for the first quarter of our bare bones operating expenses. This includes:

  • $2,000 for two facilitators—a postpartum doula and a lactation consultant—who are ready to lead two different weekly support groups for new parents—one for new parents and one for lactation help
  • $2,500 to cover renting a space at a local yoga studio, as well as advertising and supplies—like snacks and hair ties (postpartum shedding!)
  • ~10% to cover crowdfunding fees

HOW WE WILL GROW

Over time, we hope to make enough through our classes to cover our expenses. We also will be seeking to build a fiscal sponsorship relationship with a maternal and child health-related 501c3 to further help ensure that Happy Babies Parent Education is a sustainable endeavor.

THANK YOU!

Thank you so much for reading and watching! Please help us reach our goal of $5,000 so that Happy Babies Parent Education can provide parenting mentorship and community for new parents in Seattle. And, please! Help us spread the word by using the share tools below!

story:
Doctors need help too.

specialty Training

Everyone needs a doctor at some point. I started with my journey to become a Neurosurgeon, today after 6 years of med school, and €30,000 in loan, I understand there is a long way to go. 

Who am I?

Hello, I'm Nishant, or as many would call me Dr. Nishant Shekhar. I just finished my medical school in Russia and taking GMC examinations on 5th November. 

My story

As a child I always wanted to become a doctor. I belong to a what many would term as a middle class family. My father is a government servant in Government of India. He has supported me through everything but I know, it's becoming difficult for him to keep supporting my dreams day by day, I want to get a licence to practice and get on the speciality register of GMC. 

Getting on the speciality register requires a lot of training and job competition in NHS is very high. With no previous experience of working in NHS, I'll have little chance to get a speciality training. 

I recently took the IELTS exam, and got an overall score of 8, but just 6.5 in writing due to which I'll have to retake the test. Even with a good resume the chances are slick and I know it's difficult for my father to fund me observership programmes and support me financially for re-taking IELTS, a week of observation/shadowing a doctor can cost upto £250 in London. 

Where will the money go?

- If I hit my minimum funding, the first thing  I'll do is take up a 6 week long observership and Retake IELTS, It'll greatly improve me chances later on for a training position.

- If I get my project fully funded, I'll take observership for 6-8 months which will guarantee me a specialist training position. 

- unlikely but if I do raise more money than my needs, I'll use it towards lessening my loan burden, which is huge for a middle class family in India and given the fact that my home is mortgaged for the loan. 

I'll post a weekly update on my progress. 

Thank You

Rewards

- I don't have much to offer, but I've planned a surprise for everyone who donates. 

Find us here

www.facebook.com/nishantshekhar 

Follow me or add me, and I'll keep you posted always. 

Help Me succeed! 

- You don't need to give money to help me succeed! Please share this project with anyone you think would support us – on Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, by email, telephone, in a chat over the fence or on your blog.

story:
Short Summary

Sky News:"Children are the unseen victims of Greece's debt: abandoned because of a crisis that began before many were even born"
Daily Mail:"Athens' Ark of the World youth center said four children, including a newborn baby, had been left on its doorstep in recent months."
Washington Post:"Either deserted at maternity wards days after their birth, bundled inside pillowcases, or packed in cardboard boxes dumped on the doorsteps of churches, clinics and charity centers, abandoned babies are turning up all over the country."
That is just a vague description of the big picture we are currently witnessing in Athens and the rest of the country.Whatever you imagine is not even close to reality.Just a short walk around Omonoia Square and Metaxourgeio is a proper slap in the face,a hard welcome to the cruel actuality.Street children (though the term 'street children' is problematic as it can be employed as a stigmatizing label) are among the most physically visible of all children, living and working on the roads and public squares of cities all over the country. Yet, paradoxically, they are also among the most 'invisible' and therefore hardest children to reach with vital services such as education and health-care, and the most difficult to protect.I could have  uploaded hundreds of photographs depicting kids sleeping under bridges or searching garbage bins for some food but what would be the point in that?The problem exists and gets gigantic proportions as days go by.The headlines and broadcasts of major international news channels serve as uncontradicted evidence of the obvious.
I have decided to set up a crowdfunding project exactly because i want to better the future of these children.I am quite realistic to know that i cannot change it,i cannot provide them with a decent family environment no matter how hard i want it.But every little help can make a big difference. I did not know about the crowdfunding platforms to be honest.Just very recently became familiar with this entire "new world" for me, and i believe that can really connect people of different ethnic groups,different religions and beliefs and improve our world.The economic recession has been causing an ever-increasing influx of social and economic problems and, consequently, an increase in the calls for assistance, to which the association felt the compelling need to respond to. Many people affected by the crisis have not been able to cover for their everyday needs, and child welfare organizations are experiencing dramatic budget cuts and reduced funding
I am not asking you to raise funds for the payment of the Greek debt.I do not believe that you must pay for all the corruption of Greek political scene,the tax evasion of payers and the financial mismanagement of Greek authorities. 
What i am asking you is to support our effort  for the children.In Greece there are many decades of non-profit voluntary Organizations and Institutions for Children (with special needs or not) and quite a few hundred of  Social Welfare organizations (more than 100 in Attica alone). Their main concern is defending children's rights, not just on paper but in practice as well, providing services to children on a 24-hour, 7 days a week, 365 days a year-basis, working for their physical, mental, and psychological stability. With zero financial liquidity and zero donations at the current moment are experiencing a financial deadlock, while requests for help and assistance are soaring from children and families with children.Every single Institution  receives, on a daily basis, tens of requests for help from children and families across the country. They are truly anxious about whether they will be able to continue standing by the thousands of children supported until now, but also the thousands in need from now on.The vast majority of these children are so-called “social orphans,” meaning one or both of their parents are still alive. In most of these cases, the government took the children away because of abuse or neglect. Others were simply given up by their families. Many children abandoned in Greece have disabilities or suffer from medical conditions caused by a lack of pre- and neo-natal care. Their parents tend to be poorer and less educated than the general population. Some are struggling with drug or alcohol addictions. Others still live with their parents or grandparents and have a hard time finding work. In many cases newborn abandonment is caused by the hard living conditions of their mothers. These vulnerable parents have little emotional support. They feel unprepared to take care of a baby and believe the state can offer their child a better life.Unfortunately,nowadays, that just isn’t the case. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise 300000$  in order to support Children Institutions and ensure their supply with  vital necessities 

like heating oil (on average an orphanage needs 8000 ltrs of heating oil per month), medicine and food.  Principle goal is to fund at least three (3) institutions working for children who are orphaned, abandoned or whose families are unable to care for them, as possible. Mainly orphanages, children villages and shelter Foundations will get benefit from your contributions. Due to the large amount of NPO’s, Social Welfare organizations and Children Institutions acting in Greece at the moment, the selection of the ones getting funded is very difficult. Certain criteria should be taken into account and some serious scrutinizing must occur. That is the most intractable part of the campaign in my opinion. Having to manage and dispense other people’s money is a very demanding and blameful role by itself. But when those funds are destined to support abandoned children, then , automatically, you start to feel you have so much on your plate that you’re left feeling overwhelmed and stressed out. That thought is  utterly terrifying.

What I am planning to do is distribute the funds proportionally to every single institution based on:

·  the number of children served every year,

·  its amenities,

·  the active years in the country,

·  a clean background check

·  the amount of sponsor and the volume of donations it has

After having completed the aforementioned check the relative funds would be deposited ,in the form of donation, into each Institutions bank account. Supply of heating oil, medical aid and food must be top priority. The contributors will remain informed and updated at all times, until all the money gets dispensed.


FAQ's

Why do you offer perks since this is a charity campaign?

For 2 main reasons: A)I strongly believe that every act of philanthropy must get rewarded with a small token of appreciation and B)All products are handmade and Greek, thus your contribution has a dual significance and support.

In any case, should you want to get involved but you don't want a perk, you can  simply add your contribution without selecting one.

Do you have a company (or any connection to one) that produces any of the offered perks?

Absolutely not. Neither myself, nor any of my relatives have any affiliation to any of the manufacturers/producers of the perks whatsoever. The selection of the perks was made based on : the fast availability of the products in large volumes, and the traditionality of them.

What is the main reason behind the organization of this charity campaign?

The main reason? The support of abandoned children due to Greek crisis, like stated on the title. There is no hidden meaning or catch. I am a Greek scientist, member of the academic staff of Medical School of University of Athens for more than 9 years. The reason for pursuing a scientific orientation in the field of Human Genetics was (and remains) the eradication of Genetic diseases and abnormalities in children. I am doing the best I can in order to alleviate children suffering, both in my professional career and my personal life.  Having to watch kids’ sleeping on the streets of Athens (or anywhere in the world) , engaged in begging and salvage food from garbage bins/eating the waste off dust bins it, really, exasperates and chagrins me.The government does nothing,someone must act.

Why don’t you use Paypal?

Unfortunately the latest economic crisis had detrimental effect on Paypal services as well. According to PayPal, “We are carefully following the situation in Greece, as well as developments in the negotiations between the Greek government and its lenders.”

“Due to the recent decisions of the Greek authorities on capital controls, funding of PayPal wallet from Greek bank accounts, as well as cross-border transactions, funded by any cards or bank accounts are currently not available. We aim to continue serving our valued customers in Greece in full, as we have for over a decade,” the company said in a statement.

PayPal relies on traditional banks and credit cards to transfer money, which demonstrates the difficulty in dis-intermediating banks from the flow of money.


Other Ways You Can Help

SO, there you have it! I'd love for you to fund this campaign as much as you possibly can, that will really help! For those who can't contribute financially, please support by sharing this campaign to social media. All of this will help draw others to us!

Thank you so much for your time & contribution.
