story:
I’m Stacey Marmolejo. I’m retired from corporate America and now spend my time working with kids with a passion for music. I’m organizing a trip for 20 teen musicians from our hometown of Minneapolis/St Paul MN to New Jersey and back. We’ve got 8 gigs booked in 4 cities over 10 days.

June 25   St. Paul, MN  tbd
June 26   Milwaukee, WI Horny Goat
June 27   Milwaukee, WI  Summerfest
June 28   Milwaukee, WI  Summerfest
June 29   Cleveland, OH 
June 30   Wildwood, NJ  Morey's Pier
July 1        Wildwood, NJ  Morey's Pier
July 2       Pittsburgh, PA (venue tbd)
July 3       Chicago, IL       FitzGerald American Music Festival
July 4       Chicago, IL        FitzGerald American Music Festival

 As you can imagine, the bus and hotels are the most expensive part of this trip. Even though we’re sleeping 4 students to a room, the trip is still almost $44,000.  

Every teen going is expected to raise some money for themselves. They are getting  acoustic gigs in coffee shops. They’re playing local gigs and charging a small cover at the door. 


Some have part time jobs and others are baking cookies and selling them at school. The group is organizing a Garage Sale and writing a recipe book they hope to sell on Amazon.  But as I’m sure you know, these will be time consuming efforts that realistically will only make a very small dent in the overall bill. 

The $43,860 we are raising here will pay for the tour bus, hotel rooms, meals, chaperon expenses (1-to-5 adult/student ratio) and music festival participation fees.

These 20 teen have the music chops. They have the dedication. But they don’t have the finances.  

This trip will be life-changing. And you can be a part of that.

2014 Tour Group

HERE'S HOW STUDENTS FROM LAST YEAR SAY TOUR  IMPACTED THEIR LIVES.

"Tour was a huge eye-opener for me both socially and musically. I learned some friends were friends I would spend a millennia with. Musically, I was able to realize the stress of touring and how physically and mentally demanding it was. To say I grew from the experience would be an understatement. I met amazing musicians who will stay in my mind for the rest of my life."  15 years old. Female Vocalist. 

"The tour gave me a taste of the rockstar tour life. It was really interesting to experience the "arrive, set up, play, pack up, and leave" aspect." 17 year old. Male Vocalist. 

"The tour was an invaluable way to meet other like-minded people, bond with fellow musicians, and learn the ropes of doing what I love to do. One of the best times of my entire life." 15 years old. Male Guitarist. 

"The Tour really helped me grow as a musician and really helped me bond with the other people on the tour.  We ended up becoming almost like a family.  It’s a great experience and I think everyone should be able to do it."  16 year old. Male Bass Player.

"It was fun being able to experience what it's like touring.  Having to pack up and leave to a new city each day, even if it was only for a week it was worth the experience.  Not only was it fun performing in different cities, but also being able to spend time with my friends made it something that I wish I could be able to do over and over again." 18 year old. Male Guitarist.

"The Tour was the highlight of my summer for so many reasons. I spent an amazing week, playing amazing music, with amazing people. Ever since I stepped off that tour bus at the end of the week, I have been counting down the days until I can start it all again." 14 years old. Female Vocalist. 


The Impact

RESEARCH HAS PROVEN THAT MUSIC EDUCATION:

> Improves early cognitive development, math and reading skills

> Enhances learning in other core subjects

> Develops critical thinking and leadership skills

> Fosters self-esteem and the ability to work cooperatively in teams

> Develops key brain function that not only enhances musical learning but also academic and social skills.

All of those are skills our next generation of leaders needs; whether they are leading companies or become celebrated professional musicians. 

  • Imagine if one of the students YOU support becomes the next Taylor Swift!
  • Imagine if one of the students YOU support goes on to college because this trip opens their mind to all of life's possibilities.
  • Imagine if one of the students YOU support gains the self-confidence he's been lacking because of this experience. 
Just imagine how a trip like this will impact the lives of these teens! 


Risks & Challenges

The parents of some of these kids have the financial means to write a check for their child to go but some do not.  We don't want this trip to be just for rich kids.  The teens who are going have prepared, auditioned and EARNED the right to go.  The last thing we want to do is leave anyone behind because they can't afford it. 

If we don't raise enough money for the tour as planned today, parents will pay what they can. And if that isn't enough, we'll scale back by eliminating our furthest point gigs and reducing the number of days on the road. We sure don't WANT to do that, but it's our back-up plan. 

So you can donate with confidence that you will POSITIVELY affect a teenager.... and likely make a few dreams come true!

And if we earn MORE than we need, we'll put it in the bank for the 2016 Tour. 


Other Ways You Can Help

You may think you can't afford to contribute but we appreciate every dollar. In addition to contributing money, you can also help us by spreading the word about our tour and our financial need. 

  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
My name is Rusty May and the founder of the Bullying and School Safety (BASS) Foundation and SchoolToolsTv (STTV). STTV is a daily one minute anti-bullying and social skills curriculum that teachers access with their class online. 

STTV helps teachers and students connect and create a conversation about the social skills our children need to really succeed and currently reaches over 800 schools and classrooms and over 25,000 students watching the show everyday in the US and Canada.

Do you have one minute (yes, just one) to see what we do?



Teachers that have used STTV say that their students "achieve better academic results".

And we want to do so much more.

This year, we want to raise $25,000 to fund a free subscription to 500 schools who desperately need this kind of support. We will focus on schools that serve primarily under privileged populations (Title 1 Schools)  and military families and their children.


Our goal of $25,000 a year for the next 5 years which will allow us to provide the show to 500 new schools a year. The schools we're targeting have an average population of 500 students and that will enable us to be reaching 1,000,000 by 2020. 

Please help us reach 1,000,000 Children by 2020 and give them the social skills they need to really succeed.


  • When you donate $5, you'll receive a free copy of our children's eBook entitled Red which is a poem that helps children learn how to notice and deal with anger. We have a version for 4-6 and one for 7-10.
  • When you donate $25, you'll receive a Peace Out T-Shirt, that I use on the show everyday. Youth and Adult sizes available, depending on stock.
  • When you donate $50, you'll also receive a free 1 year subscription to STTV for the classroom of your choice.
  • When you donate $100, you'll also receive a 30 minute Skype visit from me to your classroom.
  • When you donate $500, you'll receive a free 1 year subscription to STTV for the school of your choice.
  • When you donate $1,000, you'll also receive an assembly visit from me to the school you chose for the 1 year subscription. 


More about STTV and this project:


STTV was my school counseling master's project in 2003.  I create STTV because I saw the effects that poor social skills were having in the classroom and on the playground and because I struggled with these same kinds of issues when I was in school. I knew that if I could help teachers and students talk about bullying and social emotional literacy, I could effect how students did in class and how they interacted with each other. I was right. 

The impact of this mission is huge. These are not bad children, they just have bad habits. We get cards and emails everyday from teachers and students telling us that the show is working and making a difference, both in terms of academic achievement and in terms of healthier, safer classrooms. 

Suspensions and expulsions are a pathway to prison. We can't continue to throw children away because they haven't been taught the skills they need to succeed. If not us, who and if not now, when?

The biggest challenge that we face is getting the word out to the schools who need our help and convincing them to try the program in this test driven educational environment. 

Teacher need to be told that it's okay to develop the whole child and to realize that a child won't succeed in their classroom unless the child knows that the teacher cares more about them as a person then they do about their test scores. 

Thank you for your time and support and please use the tools here on Indiegogo to get the word out to everyone you know who cares about children and the sate of education in this country.

story:
Who am I?

Hello, my name is Tommaso, Tom for friends, I am currently attending my last year of high school here in Genova, Italy. I have been living here all my life. When I was little I had the opportunity to learn English. Since 8th Grade, I started thinking what I wanted to do. What college I wanted to attend and what career to pursue. 

After participating in many co-curricular activities, getting involved with the community and taking many English language exams, I decided that I wanted to become a doctor. I know it is not the easiest or the shortest career a person would want. But I like helping people, I care for the people around me.

I therefore decided to take the medicine entrance exam in Italy. I studied much, but I did not reach the results I had wished for. I therefore decided that if I wanted to fully pursue my career in medicine, I had to apply also abroad. That is what I did, I applied to two American Universities and got accepted. 

My accomplishemnts

I am very happy for my accomplishments. However, an issue arises. In Italy, the public university fee is very little and can be easily be fulfilled by most of the Italian population. However, I understood that the fees in the US are much higher. I know that for what you get, when dealing with student help, scholarships and basic requirements it is reasonable. At the same time, I have a brother and a sister. My parents cannot afford to pay all the fee even if I was a single child, lets not talk about having two siblings. My parents have decided not to spend all of the money helping me as they would have to help my brother and sister too.  I agreed with them and therefore had to find a solution.

The Aim

The aim of this campaign is to raise money for part of my tuition at one of the two universities. My parents have done the best to ensure a n education for me. They will still help me in the future, but I have to find solutions for my goal. I really wish I will one day be able to go and study in the US.

Thank you

Tommaso

story:
Little Brinks 

in 2008 Danny and I walked into a small NPO in Elsies River in Cape Town, where we saw families waiting for food and help, for their family members. Then and there we decided to make a difference in their lives and help where we could, as no child should have to go to bed hungry.

What We Need & What You Get.

we need long life food, toiletries and cleaning products as we try and give families in need the basics making a month easier on them and then ask them to help the community in return, by helping another family or someone going through hard times.

The Impact

  • people needing help, do not know where to go or are too ashamed of not being able to provide for their families so they keep quiet and struggle, we have a 100% anonymity policy and we WILL NOT judge anyone trying to help their kids.
  • children come first and we have managed to get children out of some horrific situations and are happy to say that they are now placed in care and we still see them.
  • helping families in need shows people, that people still care and that the work can actually be a good place. 
  • Once someone has a little hope they are motivated to help others and we have seen this over and over where once given a break, families then help other families and so on and so on.  

Risks & Challenges

  • Going into some of these homes are not only a risk for me but for whoever is with me as we never know if the community (mostly very poor and dangerous) will accept me or if the family I am seeing is struggling with drugs or other issues, that could be a danger, so we try to do as much homework as possible on the family, phone calls, police back up if needed and a good car to get the heck out of there !

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please share as much as possible 
  • get in touch if you can make a meal for a family in need 
  • donate your time 
  • collect clothing at work 
  • collect food 
  • collect toys 
  • collect medical supplies
  • wrap gifts in November for the party we have for 150 children 
  • collect gifts

story:
Special Edition Perks


We are thrilled to announce special edition perks from Dengue Fever, the popular indie band known for their signature blend of Cambodian pop and psychedelic rock. They’ve generously donated signed CD’s of their new album, The Deepest Lake, and kramas (traditional Cambodian scarves) embroidered with the Dengue Fever cyclo logo. We only have a limited number of these perks, so hurry and tell your friends!

Check out their endorsement video of Let’s Read! Asia:


You can find more on Dengue Fever and their amazing work here. 



Thanks to our supporters for helping us raise more than $25,000 in the first week! Here's a video message from our colleague in Phnom Penh.



Look who's talking about us
        


Many children in Asia do not have access to engaging, colorful storybooks that inspire a lifelong love of reading. Often, school textbooks are the only reading material available as children’s books are too expensive for the average family, especially in rural areas. Realizing this great need, Books for Asia is launching Let’s Read!, a project that uses low-cost technology to enable underprivileged children to attain the most essential of childhood experiences – the magic of becoming lost in a story. 

The Cambodia Pilot Project

Let's Read! will pilot in 5 schools and 2 mobile libraries serving low-income communities in Cambodia. Each site will be equipped with Android tablets on which a digital library app developed by our technology partner, Library For All, will provide access to picture books in Khmer (the local language) and English. After the pilot phase, we will scale the project in Cambodia and adapt Let’s Read! for roll out to other countries in Asia. 

As children learn first and best in their mother tongue, we are curating a starter collection of 50 Khmer-language books comprised of some of the best children's books published in Cambodia. Few children's e-books exist so we are collaborating with Cambodian publishers to license and digitize their material. By participating in this project, the publishers will gain valuable experience working with e-books, receive digitized copies of their books, and have access to usage data.  Since bilingual ability improves educational and employment opportunities, we are additionally supplying 50 English-language books.

Khmer storybooks by Sipar, which will be available through the library

How does the digital library work?

The digital library app created by Library For All was designed for developing country contexts where internet and electricity access is often limited. The app does not need internet access to be used, only to download additional books. Data and battery usage is minimal. And, the app interface is entirely in Khmer, allowing ease of use by Cambodian students and teachers. 

The e-book collection will be used for weekly storytime sessions, reading festivals, and other related activities. The participating schools and mobile libraries will utilize the app's robust analytics to track student progress and provide individualized attention.


                                                           Sipar Mobile Library                 Photo by: Kwanseok Lee


Isn't it too soon for a digital library?

Cambodia is a young population, with 60% under the age of 30. As smartphones and tablets become increasingly affordable, more and more people are accessing information from mobile devices. Until recently it was very difficult to render the Khmer language digitally so very few educational resources in Khmer are available online for children. To bridge this gap, we’ve worked closely with our tech partner to render Khmer storybooks.  As a result, e-book donations now hold the promise of being a more cost-effective, scalable model than print books, which have high production and transportation costs. 

What have we done so far?

The Asia Foundation's Books for Asia staff on the ground have formed partnerships with two phenomenal Cambodian education organizations, Kampuchean Action for Primary Education (KAPE) and Sipar, who have the experience and know-how to successfully implement the digital library. They will work with their affiliated schools and libraries to develop fun reading programs and activities to bring the books alive. We’ve entered into licensing agreements with Khmer-language publishers already producing beautiful stories.  And we’ve partnered with the Cambodian chapter of International Board on Books for Young People (IBBY) to act as our a local content advisory board to ensure that the library’s collection responds to students’ needs.

How will your money be used?

We have the right local partners and the technology ready to go, but need your help to get Let’s Read! off the ground! The net proceeds from this campaign will enable Books for Asia to launch a successful pilot project in Cambodia and allow us to apply the knowledge gained to other Asian countries. In Cambodia, the pilot project will include the purchase of tablets, content licensing fees, and teacher training, baseline testing, monitoring and evaluation, app refinement and support benefiting 5 schools, 2 mobile libraries.

Perks


Why support us?

Books for Asia's book donations to Cambodian schools and universities - more than 900,000 books since the program's inception in 1995 - have dramatically increased access to much need education resources. Our resident local staff have deep experience in local education and development issues, as well as close relationships with extraordinary local organizations. 

Books for Asia team

We at Books for Asia believe that every child should have access to books that stimulate their imagination and open their minds to new possibilities. Although we come from different backgrounds and parts of the world —  Fiji, Nepal, the Philippines, and the U.S. —  all of us share a common love for books, children and education. Based out of our San Francisco Bay Area warehouse, we work together with our staff and partners throughout Asia to deliver needed books to schools and libraries in 21 countries.  

Our Phenomenal Partners
 
Our Early Supporters 
        

FAQs
What is Books for Asia?
Books for Asia is the leading provider of donation information resources in the region. Each year, the program reaches thousands of institutions in 21 Asian countries, connecting students, education, and local and national leaders with the knowledge they need to improve lives and expand opportunities. Books for Asia, founded in 1954, is a program of the nonprofit international development organization The Asia Foundation. Click here to learn more about Books for Asia.

Is my donation amount publicly displayed?
Yes, but you can choose to make it anonymous during checkout.

Is my donation tax deductible?
Generally, yes! We are a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, so your contributions are tax-deductible minus the fair market value of the perk that you receive. If you'd like to receive the full value of your contribution as tax-deductible, you may choose not to receive a perk. You should contact your tax advisor for a detailed explanation of tax deductions.

Can I increase my pledge once it's made?
YES! Once you donate to the campaign, you may want to change your incentive reward to a different one, or increase you donation amount. To do so, come back to this page and sign in. The pink "Contribute Now" button has been replaced with a "Manage Your Donation" button. Click it and you can enter a new amount, or choose a new incentive.

Can I upgrade my perk?
Yes, you can! Please read the how-to here .

What if I don't want a perk, I just want to contribute?
No problem! Click on the "Contribute now" button, add the additional amount and select 'no perk'.

When will I receive my perk?
Once the campaign ends, we will immediately start to ship out the perks.

I'm not in the US. Can I still donate to the project?
Yes, you can donate from anywhere in the world! However, we are sorry but our perks are unavailable for international shipping.

How do I contact you?
You can reach out to the team at booksforasia.info@asiafoundation.org. Feel free to email with any questions, comments, and feedback that you may have.

** A note for all funders outside the US - your donation will be received and processed in US dollars, so your credit card will show a different amount than the number you plugged in at Indiegogo. i.e. $500US=$511CAN or etc.**
story_txt:
Special Edition Perks

We are thrilled to announce special edition perks from Dengue
Fever, the popular indie band known for their signature blend of Cambodian pop
and psychedelic rock. They’ve generously donated signed CD’s of their new
album, The Deepest Lake, and kramas
(traditional Cambodian scarves) embroidered with the Dengue Fever cyclo logo. We
only have a limited number of these perks, so hurry and tell your friends! 
Check out their endorsement video of Let’s Read! Asia:

You can find more on Dengue Fever and their amazing work here. 


Thanks to our supporters for helping us raise more than $25,000 in the first week! Here's a video message from our colleague in Phnom Penh.




Look who's talking about us


        






Many children in Asia do not have
access to engaging, colorful storybooks
that inspire a lifelong love of reading. Often, school textbooks are the
only reading material available as children’s books are too expensive for the
average family, especially in rural areas. Realizing this great need, Books for
Asia is launching Let’s Read!, a
project that uses low-cost technology to enable underprivileged children to
attain the most essential of childhood experiences – the magic of becoming lost
in a story. 





The Cambodia Pilot Project
 Let's Read! will pilot in 5 schools and 2 mobile libraries serving low-income communities in Cambodia. Each site will be equipped with
Android tablets on which a digital library app developed by our technology partner, Library For All, will provide access to picture books in Khmer (the local language) and
English. After the pilot phase, we will scale the project in Cambodia and adapt Let’s Read! for roll out to other
countries in Asia. 
As children learn first and best
in their mother tongue, we are curating a starter collection of 50
Khmer-language books comprised of some of the best children's books published in Cambodia. Few children's e-books exist so we are collaborating with Cambodian publishers to license and digitize their material. By participating in this project, the publishers will gain valuable
experience working with e-books, receive digitized copies of their books, and
have access to usage data.  Since
bilingual ability improves educational and employment opportunities, we are
additionally supplying 50 English-language books.








Khmer storybooks by Sipar, which will be available through the library
How does the digital library work?

The digital library app created by Library For All was designed for developing country contexts where internet and electricity access is often limited. The app does not need internet access to be used, only to download additional books. Data and battery usage is minimal. And, the app interface is entirely in Khmer, allowing ease of use by Cambodian students and teachers. 
The e-book collection will be used for weekly storytime sessions, reading festivals, and other related activities. The participating schools and mobile libraries will utilize the app's robust analytics to track student progress and provide individualized attention.

                                                           Sipar Mobile Library                 Photo by: Kwanseok Lee  
Isn't it too soon for a digital library?


Cambodia is a young population,
with 60% under the age of 30. As smartphones and tablets become increasingly
affordable, more and more people are accessing information from mobile devices.
Until recently it was very difficult to render the Khmer language digitally so very
few educational resources in Khmer are available online for children. To bridge
this gap, we’ve worked closely with our tech partner to render Khmer
storybooks.  As a result, e-book
donations now hold the promise of being a more cost-effective, scalable model
than print books, which have high production and transportation costs. 



What have we done so far?
The Asia Foundation's Books for Asia staff on the
ground have formed partnerships with two phenomenal Cambodian education
organizations, Kampuchean
Action for Primary Education (KAPE) and Sipar, who have the experience and know-how to
successfully implement the digital library. They will work with their
affiliated schools and libraries to develop fun reading programs and activities
to bring the books alive. We’ve entered into licensing agreements with
Khmer-language publishers already producing beautiful stories.  And
we’ve partnered with the Cambodian chapter of International Board on
Books for Young People (IBBY) to act as our a local content advisory board to ensure
that the library’s collection responds to students’ needs.
How will your money be used?





We have the right local partners and
the technology ready to go, but need your help to get Let’s Read! off the ground! The net proceeds from this campaign
will enable Books for Asia to launch a successful pilot project in Cambodia and
allow us to apply the knowledge gained to other Asian countries. In Cambodia,
the pilot project will include the purchase of tablets, content licensing fees,
and teacher training, baseline testing, monitoring and evaluation, app refinement and support benefiting 5 schools, 2 mobile libraries.


Perks







Why support us?
Books for Asia's book donations to Cambodian schools and universities - more than 900,000 books since the program's inception in 1995 - have dramatically increased access to much need education resources. Our resident local staff have deep experience in local education and development issues, as well as close relationships with extraordinary local organizations. 
Books for Asia team


We at Books for Asia believe that every child should have
access to books that stimulate their imagination and open their minds to new possibilities.
Although we come from different backgrounds and parts of the world —  Fiji, Nepal, the Philippines, and the U.S. —  all of us share a common love for books, children and education. Based out
of our San Francisco Bay Area warehouse, we work together with our staff and partners
throughout Asia to deliver needed books to schools and libraries in 21
countries.  


Our Phenomenal Partners


 




 Our Early Supporters 



        







FAQs
What is Books for Asia?Books for Asia is the leading provider of donation
information resources in the region. Each year, the program reaches thousands
of institutions in 21 Asian countries, connecting students, education, and
local and national leaders with the knowledge they need to improve lives and
expand opportunities. Books for Asia, founded in 1954, is a program of the nonprofit international development organization The Asia Foundation. Click here to learn more about Books for Asia.


Is my donation amount publicly displayed?Yes, but you can choose to make it anonymous during checkout.
Is my donation tax deductible?Generally, yes! We are a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, so your contributions are tax-deductible minus the fair market value of the perk that you receive. If you'd like to receive the full value of your contribution as tax-deductible, you may choose not to receive a perk. You should contact your tax advisor for a detailed explanation of tax deductions. 
Can I increase my pledge once it's made?YES! Once you donate to the campaign, you may want to change your
incentive reward to a different one, or increase you donation amount. To do so,
come back to this page and sign in. The pink "Contribute Now" button
has been replaced with a "Manage Your Donation" button. Click it and
you can enter a new amount, or choose a new incentive.
Can I upgrade my perk?Yes, you can! Please read the how-to here .
What if I don't want a perk, I just want to contribute?No problem! Click on the "Contribute now" button, add the
additional amount and select 'no perk'.
When will I receive my perk?Once the campaign ends, we will immediately start to ship out the perks.
I'm not in the US. Can I still donate to the project?Yes, you can donate from anywhere in the world! However, we are sorry but our perks are unavailable for international shipping.
How do I contact you?You can reach out to the team at booksforasia.info@asiafoundation.org.
Feel free to email with any questions, comments, and feedback that you may
have.
** A note for all funders outside the US - your donation will be
received and processed in US dollars, so your credit card will show a different
amount than the number you plugged in at Indiegogo. i.e. $500US=$511CAN or
etc.**

story:
What Is two&?

Elmo & Zoe Love founded two& in 2014.  A beer and wine bar with a bike shop, art, and antiques. A real local business; talented people doing what they are good at, not  just a "theme" or "concept".

  • 1517 E. Las Olas Blvd, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33301
  • We need a full liquor license to expand our appeal, and keep growing our clientele.
  • Full liquor service will increase our revenues 30-100% and beyond.
  • We will continue to have the best bar prices on Las Olas Blvd.
  • This is an idea worth supporting! Help us thrive financially, and promote cycling in South Florida.

You can be a part of something FUN that actually makes cycling safer!

What We Need:

We are trying to raise $40,000

  • A 4COP Liquor license costs over $155,000.
  • $40,000 covers our down payment, transfer fees, and upgraded insurance.
  • If we make only half the goal amount, we can lease a liquor license.
  • We will get a 4cop license one way or another, but we would rather involve the global cycling community than sell part of our business to investors.
  • Check out our perks!! No matter how much or how little we raise, your contribution will be worth the expense.

The Impact two& will make on South FL

South Florida is NOT considered a safe place to ride bicycles. We aim to PERMANENTLY change that perception; it WILL be safer, beginning NOW.

  • Riding bikes when you go out for drinks makes EVERYONE safer.
  • We have a strong local following, and have been in business since August 2014.
  • We are succeeding, but we can do more to promote cycling and safety with the extra income and appeal of full liquor.
  • If you ride here and take a cab home, your bike is safe with us, AND YOUR CAR IS SAFE AT HOME!

This Is Important.

Cycling is not common enough. There are many motorists who see cycling as a threat to their way of life. 

  • The Status quo, drinking and driving, is very powerful. 
  • Many people feel they have a right to endanger others' lives!

Other Ways You Can Help:

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Stop by and have a drink, buy a bike, or get your bike repaired.
  • Tell your friends about who we are and what we are trying to achieve.
  • We may survive without your help, but we can BLOW UP if you take part!

two&liquor

T-shirt Options

Pick a shirt below, and choose your color at the very bottom. We will contact you via email to get your size/color/design choice.

Shirt 1

Shirt 2

Shirt 3

Shirt 4

Shirt 5

Shirt 6

Shirt 7

Shirt 8

story:
Help us bring together highly innovative educators, scholars, designers and community leaders for a three-day workshop. During this workshop participants will develop hands-on activities and learning materials for a toolkit designed to broaden students’ minds and foster a sense of global citizenship and tolerance. Toolkits will be piloted in classrooms across the country and then widely distributed for free.

About Nobis Project

Founded in 2008, Nobis Project, Inc., is a non-profit educational organization that supports and collaborates with educators in providing young people with an education that prepares them to become informed, active, caring and responsible global citizens, both at home and abroad. Every year Nobis Project works with hundreds of teachers across the US. More and more we hear from them that our schools need to rekindle the connection between education and citizenry, ethics and empathy. In service-learning projects the classroom walls disappear and teachers and community leaders work together as partners in teaching youth. When this happens learning becomes more relevant and meaningful for students and through altruism they learn the value of actively participating in their community. Nobis Project is committed to making sure that teachers have the tools, knowledge and confidence to engage their students in globally focused, service-learning projects.

We Need You

This campaign seeks funding to:

  • Convert our Nobis Global Action Curriculum into a free ebook for teachers. This research-based and teacher-tested, service-learning curriculum prepares educators to teach their K-12 students to critically analyze issues that impact our global society and to take action in a meaningful way.
  • Host a three-day Think Tank workshop to bring together highly innovative teachers, scholars, community leaders, and students to develop an accompanying toolkit for the ebook. The toolkit will include interactive lesson plans and corresponding materials to use with grades K-12 that will support the Nobis Global Action Curriculum and help educators overcome the initial preparation hurdle.

The ebook has already produced positive results in pilot projects by a handful of teachers. By completing the ebook, with expanded examples from real classrooms and the accompanying toolkit, we hope to make it available to thousands of educators around the world!

What Are the Components of the Project?

Ebook

The Nobis Global Action Curriculum ebook compiles a rich body of materials, project examples, best practices and templates  for educators to use in implementing globally focused service-learning. The content has been written and practiced but needs final editing and graphic design work in order to be shared with teachers everywhere.

Think Tank

Some of the best resources in education are other educators. Nobis will bring together highly innovative educators, scholars, designers and community leaders for a three-day workshop in order to develop a toolkit to accompany the Nobis Global Action Curriculum ebook. Teachers will develop a toolkit to guide implementation of the ebook in the classroom. The toolkit will contain practical activities and corresponding materials that are designed to broaden students’ minds and foster a sense of global citizenship and tolerance.

Think Tank participants will each have the chance to present about the challenges and successes in their fields:

  • Teachers will share project examples from their classrooms.
  • Academic scholars will share about new research and trends in theirs fields, which may include: Global Citizenship Education, Cultural Studies, Gender and Women’s Studies, Global Economics, K-12 Service-Learning, Community Engagement.
  • Community leaders will share about the problems their communities face and the impact of the solution initiatives they are involved in.

Think Tank participants will then be led through a series of design thinking exercises in order to:

  • Identify an initial six activities and corresponding materials for the toolkit.
  • Develop sketches of materials for prototyping.
  • Write activity instructions.

Following the Think Tank, participants will continue to work together in developing and piloting prototypes.

The educational goals encompassed by the toolkit include:

  • Support the Nobis Global Action Curriculum with materials and activities to help educators overcome the initial preparation hurdle.
  • Encourage inquiry and solutions-based learning among students.
  • Identify links with other subjects such as mathematics, art, history, social studies and science to support interdisciplinary learning and present a holistic view of our world.
  • Make students aware of our global interdependence and interconnectedness.
  • To foster respect of difference among cultures.

Target users of the toolkit include:

  • Schools / Teachers
  • Afterschool programs
  • Museums
  • Independent educators

Who will attend:

A minimum of 20 people will be invited to attend, these include but are not limited to:
Scholars
  • Marcy Lowe, M.S., President at Datu Research, Durham, NC
  • Jane Rago, Ph.D., Director of Gender & Women's Studies, Assistant Professor, Languages, Literature, and Philosophy, Armstrong State University, Savannah, GA
  • Robert Shumer, Ph.D., Community Faculty, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN
Teachers
  • Julia Alexander, M.A., M.Ed., Grades 1/2 Gradehead, Shady Hill School, Cambridge, MA
  • Christel Greiner Butchart, Chair of Peaceful Schools, NC, Middle School Teacher, Carolina Friends School, Durham, NC
  • Angela Grosse, High School Teacher, Beach High School, Savannah, GA
  • Bonnie Jackson, 2nd Grade Teacher, Caedom School, New York, NY
  • Makai Kellogg, 3 Year-Old Lead Teacher, School for Friends, Washington, DC
  • Jillian McRae, High School Teacher, Ossining High School, Ossining, NY
  • Will Nisbet, 4th Grade Lead Teacher, Maret School, Washington, DC
  • Christopher Schell, Middle School Teacher, Charles Ellis Montessori Academy, Savannah, GA
  • Alex Zinnes, Middle School Teacher, Friends School of Atlanta, Atlanta, GA
Community Leaders
  • Dare Dukes, Executive Director of Deep Center, Savannah, GA
  • Dameion B. Fowler, Founder, PISB Publications, Myrtle Beach, SC
  • Sean Higgins, Lead Interpretation and Education Specialist, North Carolina Division of Parks and Recreation, Raleigh, NC
  • Molly Lieberman, Program Director/Founder Loop It Up Savannah of the West Broad Street YMCA, Savannah, GA
  • Patricia Stewart, Ph.D., Retired Educator/Psychologist, Savannah, GA
  • Erika D. Tate, Ph.D., Founding Chief Executive Officer, Bluknowledge LLC, Savannah, GA

Where Will Your Contributions Go?

We are hoping to raise $15,000 (GOAL: $10,500). In order to share these valuable resources with educators across the globe we need:

  • Professional editing and design of ebook ($1400)
  • Think Tank: workshop space rental ($200), lodging ($1000), food ($1400), travel stipends for participants ($3,000)
  • Toolkit prototype fabrication ($3000)
  • Toolkit prototype distribution ($500)

Additional funds to be use for:

  • Hosting teacher training for pilot classrooms ($2500)
  • Publicity so that teachers will know that this free e-book exists ($2000)

Our Future Vision

Once the ebook is completed we will make it available for free on our website. We plan to prototype the toolkit and pilot it in 25 classrooms across the U.S. Once the pilots are complete and adjustments are made, we plan to widely distribute the toolkits with the ebook.

Risks & Challenges

Our previous experience in developing, producing, improving and delivering educational resources to educators across the U.S. means we are already prepared for many eventualities. Every project has challenges, but it is unlikely that there will be challenges we haven't come across already or won't be able to tackle. We want our backers to feel as important as we think they are and to receive their rewards on time or early.

We commit to keeping you informed of progress in the months following the campaign. Our promise to deliver is always going to be challenged by the complexities of manufacturing, production scheduling, shipping and more. Therefore, if unexpected issues occur in the delivery schedule, we will do our utmost to minimize the impact on our backers and devote ourselves to providing the best experience we can.

Other Ways You Can Help

Financial contributions are always appreciated, but there are many other ways to help this campaign! You can:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Share on facebook, talk to your friends and family who share our passion for education and building global connections.
  • Do you know someone we should invite to participate in the Think Tank? Email us with their contact information!
  • Do you know a teacher who would be interested in piloting the toolkit, tell them about the project and have them get in touch with us!
  • Interested in volunteering with Nobis Project? We are currently looking for volunteers with graphic design, marketing, social media, and writing skills.

Thank You!

Thank you for supporting Nobis Project!  You can learn more about the work we do here:  www.nobisproject.org. We are a non-profit based in Savannah, GA, and will happily issue a tax-deductible charitable receipt for donations of $100 or more* (*without a reward selected ~ it's the law).  

If you want to know more, have ideas or classroom projects to share, we’d love to hear from you! info@nobisproject.org

FAQ

What is the Nobis Global Action Curriculum?

This research-based and teacher-tested, project-based service-learning curriculum prepares educators to teach their K-12 students to critically analyze issues that impact our global society and to take action in a meaningful way. This unique curriculum offers a teachers a way of incorporating global citizenship in service-learning projects. It has proven to teach students the five dimensions of civic engagement: values, knowledge, skills, efficacy, and empathy.

Ebook Table of Contents
  • Chapter 1 – Global Service-Learning
  • Chapter 2 – Nobis Global Action Model
  • Chapter 3 – Nobis Big Ideas Framework
  • Chapter 4 – Getting Started
  • Chapter 5 – Step 1: Define
  • Chapter 6 – Step 2: Design
  • Chapter 7 – Step 3: Action & Documentation
  • Chapter 8 – Step 4: Reflection
  • Appendix – Worksheets, Resource Lists, Project Examples
Can you provide examples of what you mean by "templates"?

The appendix to the ebook will feature check lists, guidelines, tips and best practices, and examples of past projects. These organizational tools help educators successfully get started in their classrooms.

What qualifications and experience does Nobis Project Founder/Executive Director bring to this project?

Christen Higgins Clougherty, Ph.D., brings eighteen years of experience as an educator and administrator in community organizations, K-12 public, charter and independent schools, and colleges/universities. Christen attributes her commitment to using service-learning and civic engagement to promote global citizenship to her experiences as a student at the Carolina Friends School. Her honors include recognition as a National Emerging Scholar for K-12 Service-Learning Research (2008 and 2009) by the National Service-Learning Partnership at the Academy for Educational Development. Christen completed her doctoral research on the synthesis of experiential education, service-learning, creative-process theory and global citizenship education. Christen is also a founding board member of Tybee Island Maritime Academy, a project-based charter school.

What will you do with any funds raised beyond your goal?

It all goes towards supporting educators. The budget was based on professional editing, design, and promotion of the ebook as well as the workshop and prototyping of the toolkit. Extra funds will first go toward making the ebook as good as it can be, starting with having the graphic design team produce more diagrams to help make the content easier to understand. I think this should all be one graph? If we raise way more than expected, additional funds will be used to manufacture the toolkits following the pilots and support wide distribution of the ebook and toolkits.

How do I support Nobis Project now that this campaign is over?

Great Question! For those of you who  are here and for whatever reason missed the window of the Indie Go-Go campaign, no worries! You can donate directly to Nobis Project via PayPal on our web site here: http://nobisproject.org/Donate. We would love your support! And for those who don't use PayPal, our mailing address is on the bottom of that page as well. Thank You.

What does Nobis mean?

The name Nobis comes from Latin meaning “us” and roughly translates as the “us project.” Nobis is found in the song, Dona Nobis Pacem, which means “give us peace.” Through our work we hope to teach youth the skills and knowledge to achieve just that, the world as it ought to be, a world at peace.

Where Will Your Contributions Go?

We are hoping to raise $15,000 (GOAL: $10,500). In order to
share these valuable resources with educators across the globe we need:


Professional editing and design of ebook ($1400)

Think Tank: workshop space rental ($200), lodging ($1000), food ($1400), travel stipends for participants ($3,000)


Toolkit prototype fabrication ($3000)

Toolkit prototype distribution ($500)



Additional funds to be use for:


Hosting teacher training for pilot classrooms
($2500)

Publicity so that teachers will know that this
free e-book exists ($2000)



Our Future Vision
Once the ebook is completed we will make it available for free
on our website. We plan to prototype the toolkit and pilot it in 25 classrooms
across the U.S. Once the pilots are complete and adjustments are made, we plan to
widely distribute the toolkits with the ebook.


    Risks & Challenges  
Our previous experience in developing, producing, improving
and delivering educational resources to educators across the U.S. means we are
already prepared for many eventualities. Every project has challenges, but it
is unlikely that there will be challenges we haven't come across already or
won't be able to tackle. We want our backers to feel as important as we think
they are and to receive their rewards on time or early. 
We commit to keeping you informed of progress in the months
following the campaign. Our promise to deliver is always going to be challenged
by the complexities of manufacturing, production scheduling, shipping and more.
Therefore, if unexpected issues occur in the delivery schedule, we will do our
utmost to minimize the impact on our backers and devote ourselves to providing
the best experience we can.
  Other Ways You Can Help Financial contributions are always appreciated, but there are many other ways to help this campaign! You can:  Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Share on facebook, talk to your friends and family who share our passion for education and building global connections.
 Do you know someone we should invite to participate in the Think Tank? Email us with their contact information!
Do you know a teacher who would be interested in piloting the toolkit, tell them about the project and have them get in touch with us!
Interested in volunteering with Nobis Project? We are currently looking for volunteers with graphic design, marketing, social media, and writing skills. 
   Thank You!


Thank you for supporting Nobis Project!  You can learn
more about the work we do here:  www.nobisproject.org.
We are a non-profit based in Savannah, GA, and will happily
issue a tax-deductible charitable receipt for donations of $100 or more*
(*without a reward selected ~ it's the law).   
If you want to know more, have ideas
or classroom projects to share, we’d love to hear from you! info@nobisproject.org 
FAQ
What is the Nobis Global Action Curriculum? 

This research-based and teacher-tested, project-based service-learning
curriculum prepares educators to teach their K-12 students to critically
analyze issues that impact our global society and to take action in a
meaningful way. This unique curriculum offers a teachers a way of incorporating global citizenship in service-learning projects. It has proven to teach
students the five dimensions of civic engagement: values, knowledge, skills,
efficacy, and empathy. 
Ebook Table of Contents


Chapter 1 – Global Service-Learning
Chapter 2 – Nobis Global Action Model
Chapter 3 – Nobis Big Ideas Framework
Chapter 4 – Getting Started


Chapter 5 – Step 1: Define
Chapter 6 – Step 2: Design


Chapter 7 – Step 3: Action & Documentation


Chapter 8 – Step 4: Reflection


Appendix – Worksheets, Resource Lists, Project Examples
Can you provide examples of what you mean by "templates"?The appendix to the ebook will feature
check lists, guidelines, tips and best practices, and examples of past
projects. These organizational tools help educators successfully get started in
their classrooms.What qualifications and
experience does Nobis Project Founder/Executive Director bring to this project?
Christen Higgins Clougherty, Ph.D., brings eighteen years of experience as an educator and
administrator in community organizations, K-12 public, charter and independent
schools, and colleges/universities. Christen attributes her commitment to using
service-learning and civic engagement to promote global citizenship to her
experiences as a student at the Carolina Friends School. Her honors include
recognition as a National Emerging Scholar for K-12 Service-Learning Research
(2008 and 2009) by the National Service-Learning Partnership at the Academy for
Educational Development. Christen completed her doctoral research on the
synthesis of experiential education, service-learning, creative-process theory
and global citizenship education. Christen is also a founding board member of
Tybee Island Maritime Academy, a project-based charter school.
What will you do with any funds raised beyond
your goal? 
It all goes towards supporting educators. The budget was based
on professional editing, design, and promotion of the ebook as well as the
workshop and prototyping of the toolkit. Extra funds will first go toward
making the ebook as good as it can be, starting with having the graphic design
team produce more diagrams to help make the content easier to understand. I
think this should all be one graph? If we raise way more than expected,
additional funds will be used to manufacture the toolkits following the pilots
and support wide distribution of the ebook and toolkits.
How do I support Nobis
Project now that this campaign is over? 
Great Question! For those of you who  are here and for whatever reason missed the window of the
Indie Go-Go campaign, no worries! You can donate directly to Nobis Project via
PayPal on our web site here: http://nobisproject.org/Donate.
We would love your support! And for those who don't use PayPal, our mailing
address is on the bottom of that page as well. Thank You. 
What does Nobis mean?
The name Nobis comes from Latin meaning “us” and roughly
translates as the “us project.” Nobis is found in the song, Dona Nobis Pacem,
which means “give us peace.” Through our work we hope to teach youth the skills
and knowledge to achieve just that, the world as it ought to be, a world at
peace.

story:
Summary

The Australian Sugar Industry was founded on the back of hard-working pioneers - they have a story to tell.  The use of South Sea Islander labour had a significant impact on the social attitudes in Australia in the late 1800's. This was followed by manual cutters from all over the world, a large number coming from Italy and migrating to Australia.

We want to provide more information to the visitor so they can understand what it took to create a thriving and prosperous primary industry in Australia.

We need to do more to attract passers-by, so they are encouraged to stop and experience the journey through the museum.  Most of the comments in the Museum's Visitors' Book refer to signage along the road, which attracted their attention and encouraged them to stop.

The Australian Sugar Industry - millers and growers - have committed to ensure financial stability for the operation of the museum in the short-term, with a planned review of operations and implementation of any necessary changes.  This campaign is a part of that phase, as an interim measure, to help build up the level of visitors coming to the museum.

The museum is run completely by a team of enthusiastic volunteers.  There are no paid staff.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The current exhibits are mainly static displays of artifacts with historical interest, revolving around the sugar industry.  Some machinery requires an explanation of how it was used.   This will be achieved through audio visual displays in front of each exhibit.
  • We are offering different levels of gifts for different amounts of donations.  Packages range from the Queensland Sugar Industry's  "Journey of the Jelly Bean" DVD (which provides information about the sugar industry from planting through to producing sugar crystals, as well an overview of the Australian Sugar Industry),  our unique metal medallion, to the book "Sweet Talking", which contains stories from people who were involved in the sugar industry - growers, engineers and mill workers, with personal images.
  • Our aim is to raise $30,000.   If, however, we do not reach that target all donations will be put toward improvements to exhibits and additional promotional signage, to the limit the available funds will provide.
  • You can help by spreading the word about our fundraising campaign on your Facebook, or using your email contact list.  If you manage a website, include a link to this campaign.  Tell your friends to help us achieve our goal.

The aim of our campaign

  • We need to improve the exhibits, but the major constraint is available funding to undertake the installation and development of those improvements.  With the impacts of ever-increasing operational costs, the income generated by the museum is barely enough to keep the museum operating.  The improvements to the exhibits will provide an improved experience to the visitor and encourage more people to visit the museum. 
  • If operational costs continue to rise and visitor numbers remain static the museum may have to close and this will be a tragic outcome for this unique museum, which is the only one in Australia totally focused on a single primary industry and one of only a few in the world.
  • The volunteer-based team at the museum are always developing new ideas and changes to the exhibits.  In 2012 an interpretative section was created, with the support of an Australian Federal Government program and sugar industry partnerships.  This has been a huge hit with visitors, especially international visitors, and allows the process from planting to refining to be explained. 
  • The team also constructed a half-sized replica of the "barracks"-style accommodation the cane cutters lived in.  It contains artifacts commonly used in dwellings from the manual cane cutting era.
  • Without capital the improvements cannot be undertaken.  At present there are no surplus funds for the Sugar Museum to allocate.  To enable important improvements to be undertaken we need your help.

Overview

We understand that our campaign may not be as exciting as some but we believe that you and many others want to ensure that the Australian Sugar Industry Museum remains the iconic central place for the retention of historical information and articles of the Australian Sugar Industry (including the provision of interesting facts about the sugar industry: how the sugarcane plant grows, how it is harvested and how the juice from the plant is made into sugar crystals).

We also plan to engage with as many people associated with the Australian Sugar Industry as possible.  We want them to help us connect with others.

For a small donation all interested individuals can help us reach our goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Put a post on your Facebook page,
  • Circulate details of this site and the campaign through your email address book,
  • Put a link to this campaign on websites that you manage,
  • Tell your friends about this campaign,
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it - thank you for your support.

story:
The American Sports Organization is raising funds to donate sports equipment  to needy schools/kids in the USA and in Africa. ASO is working with LEFT to provide Soccer equipment for needy kids in Liberia Africa and ASO needs donated sports equipment in good to excellent condition! Soccer and Basketball are the two sports we are concentrating on in both Africa and in the USA.  

Liberia is the African American founded country in Africa and needs our help. In the 1820's freed African American Slaves went to Liberia and started the country in the 1840's. It has gone through a terrible Civil War and a devastating Ebola outbreak and they need help to get back on their feet. They have a wonderful female President named Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and she won the Nobel Peace Prize and is Harvard Educated! Please help the kids of Liberia through sports! See the Liberian Flag, the Star represents Freedom, the Blue represents Africa and the strips represent the founders of the Country!

ASO wants to develop areas of Liberia so African Americans can safely travel there to explore their roots! We want to eventually charter flights to Liberia so African American can see their ancestral source of origin. We want to develop educational tours showing African Americans the history of West Africa and to provide DNA tests showing the Americans what regions of Africa (and the World) their ancestors came from.        

We need to pay for equipment and shipping so if you can spare $1, $5 or $100 it will be greatly appreciated. If you have sports equipment in good to excellent condition please send it to ASO, PO Box 7712, Philadelphia, PA 19101 Attention: Rev. Jim E. Stephenson. Please do not send anything over 40 lbs. or to big like Goal Posts but soccer balls, basketballs, nets, rims, etc. would be awesome!  

In God and Jesus,

Rev. Jim E. Stephenson

story:
The Sellam Circus School is coming to Maine - and we need you!


The Sellam Circus School has found a great community in Biddeford, Maine . . . and we need you!  With your support, we will establish our permanent headquarters in a historically significant building in the downtown district.  Help us to open our doors in September!  

Meet Sellam . . .  

My name is Sellam El Ouahabi, and I’ve worked in the circus all my life. That's me, standing on the shoulders of my friends and brothers, living my dream of a life in the circus.  I started performing professionally in Morocco and Spain at the age of 13, with the Ali Hassani Troupe, and later, the famed Ben Karim Troupe.  My time with the Hassani and the Ben Karim troupes was the beginning of my dream come true:  To travel the world with circus.  

When I was a child in the circus, I had to be tough.  Luckily, I had my eyes open: I was born in Tangier, and I was a street-wise boy. You could say that circus gave me a second chance.  

I came from a large family, and I had their love following me around the world.  But I saw other kids who did not have such support.  This is not an easy industry.  You push your body to defy gravity, every day.  You know you must do your best, or you will be replaced.  With so much pressure, it is easy to get hurt.  I learned how important it was to have good mentors, not just good coaches.  A mentor helps you to train your mind, in addition to your body.

In the end, I worked for over 26 different circuses and performed on 3 different continents.  I even performed for the Queen of England – twice. Circus has been my life . . . 

After 30 years of performing, I discovered coaching, and that is when I became truly happy in the circus.  In 2008, I transitioned to full-time coaching and retired as a performer. 

Now, I am doing something I never dared to dream before:  I am opening my own circus school. And I need your help.


A Little Bit About The Sellam Circus School . . .

. . . The Sellam Circus School is you.  

In Morocco, we have a word:  Sahela.  "Sahela" is the word we use to say many things - including honest, good, and simple.   I believe that the circus belongs to everyone, and access to Master-level training should be, well - Sahela!    

What We Do

The Sellam Circus School (LLC) is a circus arts academy based in Biddeford, Maine, that will offer both recreational and professional-level classes in circus skills and performance, as well as forums on circus history, technical courses in rigging, and practical introductions to tent maintenance and mechanics.  Ideally, The Sellam Circus School’s Professional Circus Arts Training (PCAT) course and PCAT Preparatory course is designed to conclude with one month of training and performance in the big top tent.  Our goal is to bring our students into the ring, and connect them with the tradition of circus, by ensuring their access to Master-level coaches, and the enchanting environment of the big top tent.   For our first year, we plan to rent our big top . . . but we will quickly be working toward the purchase of our very own chapiteau. 

Poised between circus instruction and cultural anthropology, The Sellam Circus School is based upon two principles:

·  Easy access to world-class, professional circus arts coaching; and

·  Preservation, sharing and promotion of the culture and traditions of traveling circus.

The Sellam Approach

The Sellam Circus School is my way to give back what I have learned. My students know that there is one standard that I will insist upon from all who attend my classes:  You must train from the heart.  Coaches enjoy students who love what they do, and students learn best from coaches with a deep love and appreciation of circus. 

The mission of The Sellam Circus School is to pass on excellent performance technique, actively preserve the traditions of circus, and provide a performance venue for graduating students.  The Sellam Circus School is committed to creating avenues for students to connect with the rich history and traditions of circus.  For that reason, the coaches at The Sellam Circus School will be carefully selected for their long experience performing in the circus ring, their effective and safe technique, and their proven understanding of the culture of circus.  Through over three decades of performance and coaching around the world, I have been connecting with the incredible people - students and coaches - that will make The Sellam Circus School a success.  There is just one last ingredient missing . . . 


Our Home!

The most important tool you can have, as a circus artist, is a strong foundation of skills.  The Sellam Circus School is working to build the same strong foundation for itself - starting with a permanent headquarters in a historically significant building in the downtown district of Biddeford.

About Biddeford, Maine . . .

Biddeford, Maine pretty much has it all:  A former mill town, the vast campus of brick factory buildings that comprise the bulk of the downtown district are now home to a thriving live/work arts community, a vibrant farm-to-table restaurant scene, tech and maker studios, and now . . . a circus school!  We’ve had our eye on Biddeford for some time, and we have a chance to make a very special building in the heart of the downtown district our permanent home. With a total of over 6,000 useable square feet, and a maximum ceiling height of 35 feet, this location offers the space and vertical pitch to work every level of aerial tricks, from beginner to advanced.

Right Here, Right Now!

Meeting our IndieGoGo goal will provide us the first, simple ingredients for a great start to our school.  Here are some of the things your donations could help us to pay for:

  • Deposit to secure our lease for permanent school space
  • Purchase of all needed circus equipment
  • An operating budget (coaching salaries, etc) for first months of business
  • Insurance and safety certification fees

. . . We Have A Wish List, Too!

Here are some of the other needed items and equipment your donations could help purchase:

  • Points and rigging to get some air time
  • Back stage curtains, ring mat and other tent dressings
  • Used, quality bleacher seating
  • A sign for the top of our tent and entrance by a local artist
  • Crash mats and foam-core tumbling tracks

We have already received some equipment donations from generous supporters, and we welcome any further such donations.  We are on our way to a well-dressed school!


Future dreams . . .

At The Sellam Circus School, we believe that opportunity to train in a big top tent is essential to the comprehensive education and evolution of every circus student - whether they are looking to simply build confidence, or build a career.  Our Professional Circus Arts Training program (PCAT) is designed to make big top time a central focus, and we have a handful of future programs that are planned for the chapiteau - including immersive camps, traveling workshops, and much more.  

However, as a startup company, our immediate focus is to establish our permanent headquarters - and your contribution to this IndieGoGo will help us accomplish just that.  We know that buying our very own tent will take time and hard work, and our business plan accommodates this reality.  Our phases of development include a progression from short-term tent rental, to the eventual purchase or our very own chapiteau.

A Little Bit About Tents 

Buying a circus tent is more complicated than you might think!  Traditionally, the best tents tend to come from Italy.  You can find good, used, well-made tents throughout Europe; unfortunately, a good tent is not always easy to find in the U.S.  For that reason, we plan to purchase our tent through European contacts and have it shipped back to the U.S.  We know it will take us a little time to buy our tent – it won’t happen instantly!  But here’s what we can tell you right now about the tent we are working to purchase:

  • Approximately 24 - 36 meter round tent (121 – 131 feet)
  • Capacity of up to 1,500 seats
  • Oval cupola
  • Minimum 40 foot interior height

This tent size is spacious, and can be used in a variety of ways:  Without seating, the expanse of space will allow us to create peripheral practice areas outside of the center ring, perfect for disciplines such as hand balance, contortion, juggling, clowning, and other activities that do not require full height.  For performances and forums, construction of bleacher seating will allow us to produce profitable, high-volume events. 


The Hook-Up

Your support for the Sellam Circus School comes with great perks!  Hey . . . we know:  It’s always nice to get a gift.  Here are some of the rewards you may enjoy for joining us in our dream: 

  • Autographed, authentic reproduction photo postcard sets from Sellam’s touring days in the circus!
  • A tee-shirt emblazoned with an always original, always hilarious #Sellamism  
  • A year of tickets to any and all Sellam Circus School shows and events! 
  • Private lessons with Sellam, and a tee-shirt to take home with you! 
  • A chance to explore Tangier, Morocco with Sellam, and experience the Moroccan technique of beach acrobatics  
  • Your name in lights!  An homage to your significant contribution in the form of your name added to an authentic circus sideshow banner, to be created by a Maine artist . . . and displayed in the school.  
  • Our undying gratitude and total happiness!  

A Message From Sellam

"I created The Sellam Circus School for those who feel they belong inside the dream of circus:  Those who want to make circus their profession, those looking for a new source of recreation, adults, children – all are welcome.  I am committed to creating an inclusive environment, and my belief that the circus belongs to everyone. 

The Sellam Circus School is intended for any size dream, be it a student who wants to build a career, or simply build confidence.  In my country, the name "Sellam" means peace . . . and that is what I hope to build with my school:  A gentle, supportive environment to learn, connect with community, and experience the joy of circus.

The Sellam Circus School will offer a range of classes, from after-school and summer programs, to technical workshops and private sessions, to semester-based professional training.  We will always work to provide opportunities for students in need, and to reflect the special community that is circus, back to our neighbors. 

Many of you who are visiting this page are my friends . . .  I invite all who have discovered this project to join in the dream of circus.  Perhaps I have worked with your son or daughter, or I have been your coach.  Maybe you have seen your children grow up in my classes, or maybe – hopefully – you have realized some of your own circus dreams during our training time together.  Perhaps we have yet to meet, and your own story of circus has yet to unfold . . . 

The Sellam Circus School needs your help.  Together, we can build a school that draws upon the beauty, discipline, and the love of the circus." 

- Sellam El Ouahabi

· 
Preservation,
sharing and promotion of the culture and traditions of traveling circus.
The Sellam ApproachThe Sellam Circus School is my way to give back
what I have learned. My students know that there is one standard that I will insist upon from all who attend my classes:  You must train from the heart.  Coaches enjoy students who love what they do,
and students learn best from coaches with a deep love and appreciation of
circus. 
The mission of The Sellam Circus School is to pass on excellent performance technique, actively preserve the traditions of
circus, and provide a performance venue for graduating students.  The Sellam Circus School is committed to creating avenues for
students to connect with the rich history and traditions of circus.  For that reason, the coaches at
The Sellam Circus School will be carefully selected for their long experience
performing in the circus ring, their effective and safe technique, and
their proven understanding of the culture of circus.  Through over
three decades of performance and coaching around the world, I have been
connecting with the incredible people - students and coaches - that will make The Sellam Circus School a success.  There is just one last ingredient
missing . . . 
Our Home!
The most important tool you can have, as a circus artist, is a strong
foundation of skills.  The Sellam Circus School is working to build the
same strong foundation for itself - starting with a permanent headquarters in a
historically significant building in the downtown district of Biddeford.
About Biddeford, Maine . . . 
Biddeford, Maine pretty
much has it all:  A former mill town, the
vast campus of brick factory buildings that comprise the bulk of the downtown
district are now home to a thriving live/work arts community, a vibrant farm-to-table
restaurant scene, tech and maker studios, and now . . . a circus school!  We’ve had our eye on Biddeford for some time,
and we have a chance to make a very special building in the heart of the
downtown district our permanent home. With a total of over 6,000 useable square feet, and a maximum ceiling height of 35 feet, this location offers the space and
vertical pitch to work every level of aerial tricks, from beginner to advanced.
Right Here, Right Now!
Meeting our IndieGoGo goal will provide us the
first, simple ingredients for a great start to our school. 
Here are some of the things your donations could help us to pay for:
Deposit to secure our lease for permanent school space

Purchase of all needed
     circus equipment

An operating budget
     (coaching salaries, etc) for first months of business
Insurance and safety
     certification fees

. . . We Have A Wish List, Too!
Here are some of the other needed items and
equipment your donations could help purchase:

Points and rigging
     to get some air time
Back stage curtains,
     ring mat and other tent dressings
Used, quality
     bleacher seating
A sign for the top
     of our tent and entrance by a local artist
Crash mats and
     foam-core tumbling tracks

We have already received some equipment donations
from generous supporters, and we welcome any further such donations.  We are on our way to a well-dressed school!Future dreams . . .At The Sellam Circus School, we believe that opportunity to train in a big top tent is essential to the comprehensive education and evolution of every circus student - whether they are looking to simply build confidence, or build a career.  Our Professional Circus Arts Training program (PCAT) is designed to make big top time a central focus, and we have a handful of future programs that are planned for the chapiteau - including immersive camps, traveling workshops, and much more.  However, as a startup company, our immediate focus is to establish our permanent headquarters - and your contribution to this IndieGoGo will help us accomplish just that.  We know that buying our very own tent will take time and hard work, and our business plan accommodates this reality.  Our phases of development include a progression from short-term tent rental, to the eventual purchase or our very own chapiteau.A Little Bit About Tents Buying a circus tent is more complicated than you might think!  Traditionally, the best tents tend to come from Italy.  You can find good, used, well-made tents throughout Europe; unfortunately, a good tent is not always easy to find in the U.S.  For that reason, we plan to purchase our tent through European contacts and have it shipped back to the U.S.  We know it will take us a little time to buy our tent – it won’t happen instantly!  But here’s what we can tell you right now about the tent we are working to purchase:
Approximately 24 - 36 meter round tent (121 – 131 feet)
Capacity of up to 1,500 seats
Oval cupola
Minimum 40 foot interior height
This tent size is spacious, and can be used in a variety of ways:  Without seating, the expanse of space will allow us to create peripheral practice areas outside of the center ring, perfect for disciplines such as hand balance, contortion, juggling, clowning, and other activities that do not require full height.  For performances and forums, construction of bleacher seating will allow us to produce profitable, high-volume events. The Hook-Up

Your support for the Sellam Circus School comes with great perks!  Hey . . . we know:  It’s
always nice to get a gift.  Here are some
of the rewards you may enjoy for joining us in our dream: 

Autographed, authentic reproduction photo postcard sets from Sellam’s touring days in the circus!

A tee-shirt emblazoned with an always
     original, always hilarious #Sellamism  

A year of tickets to any and all Sellam Circus School shows and events! 
Private lessons with Sellam, and a tee-shirt to take home with you! 
A chance to explore Tangier, Morocco with Sellam, and experience the Moroccan technique of beach acrobatics  
Your name in lights!  An homage to your
     significant contribution in the form of your name added to an authentic
     circus sideshow banner, to be created by a Maine artist . . .
     and displayed in the school.  
Our undying gratitude and total
     happiness!  

A Message From Sellam

"I created The Sellam Circus
School for those who feel they belong inside the dream of circus:  Those
who want to make circus their profession, those looking for a new source of
recreation, adults, children – all are welcome.  I am committed to creating an inclusive environment, and my belief that the circus belongs to everyone. 

The Sellam Circus School
is intended for any size dream, be it a student who wants to build a
career, or simply build confidence.  In my country, the name "Sellam" means peace . . . and that is what I hope to build with my school:  A gentle, supportive environment to learn, connect with community, and experience the joy of circus.
The Sellam Circus School will offer a range of classes,
from after-school and summer programs, to technical workshops and private
sessions, to semester-based professional training.  We will always work to provide opportunities for students in need, and to reflect the special community that is circus, back to our neighbors. 
Many of you who are
visiting this page are my friends . . .  I invite all who
have discovered this project to join in the dream of circus.  Perhaps I have worked with your son or daughter, or I have been
your coach.  Maybe you have seen your children grow up in my classes,
or maybe – hopefully – you have realized some of your own circus dreams during
our training time together.  Perhaps we have yet to meet, and your own
story of circus has yet to unfold . . . 
The Sellam Circus School
needs your help.  Together, we can build a school that draws upon the
beauty, discipline, and the love of the circus." 
- Sellam El Ouahabi

story:
I am Lorenzo Palmer, a poet and current senior at Florida Memorial University, home of the Fighting Lions. FMU is the only Historical Black College University in South Florida. I am studying to become an effective English educator, teaching young thinkers to become great minds.
I have been going to school on and off for the past ten years, due to fighting poverty, harsh socioeconomic conditions, countless setbacks, embarrassments, and the “I can't mentality.” However, I am only Two Classes away from graduating in May 2016. Unfortunately, insufficient funds has forced me to sit out for the 2015 Fall Semester, to raise the remaining balance of my tuition. Will you help me?
I am looking for five hundred people who will donate $20 to fulfill my goal: raising funds for tuition fees and college graduation. I have a hard time asking for help, but my dream is greater than my pride. I will also be hosting a benefit show as the final push for me to graduate and educate the next generation. Thanks in advance for helping me conquer the “I can’t mentality!”
